revision.comment: /* 15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE */clean up, replaced: Acta biochimica Polonica → Acta Biochimica Polonica

{{Chembox | ImageFile = 15(S)-HETE.svg | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | IUPACName = (5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z'',13''E'',15''S'')-15-Hydroxyicosa-5,8,11,13-tetraenoic acid | OtherNames = 15-HETE, 15(S)-HETE, 15(''S'')-HETE | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers | IUPHAR_ligand = 3401 | CASNo = 54845-95-3 | PubChem = 5280724 | SMILES = CCCCC[C@@H](/C=C/C=C\C/C=C\C/C=C\CCCC(=O)O)O | ChemSpiderID = 4444307 | StdInChI = 1S/C20H32O3/c1-2-3-13-16-19(21)17-14-11-9-7-5-4-6-8-10-12-15-18-20(22)23/h4-5,8-11,14,17,19,21H,2-3,6-7,12-13,15-16,18H2,1H3,(H,22,23)/b5-4-,10-8-,11-9-,17-14+/t19-/m0/s1 | StdInChIKey = JSFATNQSLKRBCI-VAEKSGALSA-N
}} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | C=20|H=32|O=3 | MolarMass = | Appearance = | Density = | MeltingPt = | BoilingPt = | Solubility = }} | Section3 = {{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards = | FlashPt = | AutoignitionPt = }} }}
'''15-Hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid''' (also termed '''15-HETE''', '''15(''S'')-HETE''', and '''15''S''-HETE''') is an [[eicosanoid]], i.e. a metabolite of [[arachidonic acid]]. Various cell types metabolize arachidonic acid to 15(''S'')-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid (15(''S'')-HpETE). This initial [[peroxide#Organic peroxides|hydroperoxide]] product is extremely short-lived in cells: if not otherwise metabolized, it is rapidly reduced to 15''(S)''-HETE. Both of these metabolites, depending on the cell type which forms them, can be further metabolized to 15-oxo-eicosatetraenoic acid (15-oxo-ETE), 5''S'',15''S''-dihydroxy-eicosatetraenoic acid (5(''S''),15(''S'')-diHETE), 5-oxo-15(''S'')-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid (5-oxo-15(''S'')-HETE, a subset of [[specialized pro-resolving mediators]] viz., the [[lipoxins]], a class of pro-inflammatory mediators, the [[eoxin]]s, and other products that have less well-defined activities and functions. Thus, 15(''S'')-HETE and 15(''S'')-HpETE, in addition to having intrinsic biological activities, are key precursors to numerous biologically active derivatives.<ref name="New aspects of the role of hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids in cell growth and cancer development">{{cite journal | pmid = 18761324 | year = 2009 | author1 = Moreno | first1 = J. J. | title = New aspects of the role of hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids in cell growth and cancer development | journal = Biochemical Pharmacology | volume = 77 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–10 | doi = 10.1016/j.bcp.2008.07.033 }}</ref><ref name="Cyclooxygenases and lipexygenases in cancer">{{cite journal | pmid = 22002716 | pmc = 3798028 | year = 2011 | author1 = Schneider | first1 = C | title = Cyclooxygenases and lipoxygenases in cancer | journal = Cancer and Metastasis Reviews | volume = 30 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 277–94 | last2 = Pozzi | first2 = A | doi = 10.1007/s10555-011-9310-3 }}</ref>
Some cell types (e.g. [[platelets]]) metabolize arachidonic acid to the [[stereoisomer]] of 15(''S'')-HpETE, 15(''R'')-HpETE. Both stereoisomers may also be formed as result of the metabolism of arachidonic acid by cellular microsomes or as a result of arachidonic acid [[auto-oxidation]]. Similar to 15(''S"'')-HpETEs, 15(''R'')-HpETE may be rapidly reduced to 15(''R'')-HETE. These ''R,S'' stereoisomers differ only in having their [[hydroxyl|hydroxy]] residue in opposite orientations. While the two ''R'' stereoisomers are sometimes referred to as 15-HpETE and 15-HETE, proper usage should identify them as ''R'' stereoisomers. 15(''R'')-HpETE and 15(''R'')-HETE lack some of the activity attributed to their ''S'' stereoisomers but can be further to metabolized to bioactive products viz., the 15(''R'') class of [[lipoxins]] (also termed [[epi-lipoxin]]s).<ref name="resolve">{{cite journal | pmid = 24656045 | pmc = 4004957 | year = 2014 | author1 = Buckley | first1 = C. D. | title = Proresolving lipid mediators and mechanisms in the resolution of acute inflammation | journal = Immunity | volume = 40 | issue = 3 | pages = 315–27 | last2 = Gilroy | first2 = D. W. | last3 = Serhan | first3 = C. N. | doi = 10.1016/j.immuni.2014.02.009 }}</ref>
15(''S'')-HETE, 15(''S'')-HpETE, and many of their derivative metabolites are thought to have physiologically important functions. They appear to act as [[hormone]]-like [[autocrine signalling|autocrine]] and [[paracrine signalling]] agents that are involved in regulating [[inflammation|inflammatory]] and perhaps other responses.<ref name="New aspects of the role of hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids in cell growth and cancer development" /><ref name="Cyclooxygenases and lipexygenases in cancer" /><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22331435 | year = 2012 | author1 = Zhu | first1 = D | title = Role of 15-lipoxygenase/15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid in hypoxia-induced pulmonary hypertension | journal = The Journal of Physiological Sciences | volume = 62 | issue = 3 | pages = 163–72 | last2 = Ran | first2 = Y | doi = 10.1007/s12576-012-0196-9 }}</ref> Clinically, drugs that are stable analogs, and therefor mimic the anti-inflammatory actions of the lipoxins and drugs that block the production or actions of the pro-inflammatory eoxins may prove useful for treating acute and chronic [[inflammatory disorders]].<ref name="pmid8087575">{{cite journal | vauthors = Leeper KV | title = Diagnosis and treatment of pulmonary infections in adult respiratory distress syndrome | journal = New Horizons (Baltimore, Md.) | volume = 1 | issue = 4 | pages = 550–62 | year = 1993 | pmid = 8087575 | doi = | url = }}</ref>
== Nomenclature and stereoisomers == 15(''S'')-HETE is unambiguously designated by a shortened version of its [[IUPAC]] name viz., 15(''S'')-hydroxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid. In this terminology ''S'' refers to the [[absolute configuration]] of the [[chirality (chemistry)|chirality]] of the hydroxy [[functional group]] at carbon position 15. Its 15(''R'') [[enantiomer]] is designated 15(''R'')-hydroxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid. ''Z'' and ''E'' give the [[cis–trans isomerism]] about each [[double bond]] [[moiety (chemistry)|moiety]] at carbon positions 5, 8, 11, and 13 with Z indicating cis and E indicating trans isomerism. Both stereoisomers are produced from their corresponding ''S'' and ''R'' 15-HpETE stereoisomers, i.e. 15(''S'')-hydroperoxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid (15(S)-HpETE) and (15''R'')-hydroperoxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid (15(R)-HpETE).
== Production == Human cells release [[arachidonic acid]] (i.e. 5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid) from its storage site in [[phospholipids]] by reactions that involve [[phospholipase C]] and/or [[lipase]] enzymes. This release is stimulated or enhanced by cell stimulation. The freed arachidonic acid is then converted to 15-hydroperoxy/hydroxy products by one or more of the following five pathways.
'''15-Lipoxygenase-1''': Cells metabolize arachidonic acid with 15-lipoxygenase-1 (i.e., 15-LO-1, [[ALOX15]]) to form 15(''S'')-HpETE as a major product and 12(''S'')-hydroperoxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',10''E'',15''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid (12(''S'')-HpETE) and 14(''S''),15(''S'')-''trans''-oxido-5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z''-14,15-leukotriene A4 as minor products; 15(''S'')-HpETE and 12(''S'')-HpETE are rapidly converted to 15(''S'')-HETE and 12(''S'')-hydroxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',10''E'',15''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid ([[12-Hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid|12(''S'')-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid]]), (i.e. 12(''S'')-HETE), respectively, or further metabolized through other enzyme pathways; 14(''S''),15(''S'')-''trans''-oxido-5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z''-14,15-leukotriene A<sub>4</sub> is metabolized by 15-LO-1 to various isomers of 8,15(''S'')-dihydroxy-5''S'',8''S'',''11Z'',13''S''-eicosatetraenoic acids, e.g. 8,15(S)-LTB<sub>4</sub>'s.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 6318 | year = 1975 | author1 = Schewe | first1 = T | title = A lipoxygenase in rabbit reticulocytes which attacks phospholipids and intact mitochondria | journal = FEBS Letters | volume = 60 | issue = 1 | pages = 149–52 | last2 = Halangk | first2 = W | last3 = Hiebsch | first3 = C | last4 = Rapoport | first4 = S. M. | doi=10.1016/0014-5793(75)80439-x}}</ref><ref>''J. Biol. Chem'' 256:9483-9582, 1981</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 6438089 | year = 1984 | author1 = Hopkins | first1 = N. K. | title = Biosynthesis and metabolism of 15-hydroperoxy-5,8,11,13-eicosatetraenoic acid by human umbilical vein endothelial cells | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 259 | issue = 22 | pages = 14048–53 | last2 = Oglesby | first2 = T. D. | last3 = Bundy | first3 = G. L. | last4 = Gorman | first4 = R. R. }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 1566855 | year = 1992 | author1 = Sigal | first1 = E | title = Cloning of human airway 15-lipoxygenase: Identity to the reticulocyte enzyme and expression in epithelium | journal = The American Journal of Physiology | volume = 262 | issue = 4 Pt 1 | pages = L392–8 | last2 = Dicharry | first2 = S | last3 = Highland | first3 = E | last4 = Finkbeiner | first4 = W. E. }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal | pmid = 9177185 | pmc = 21017 | year = 1997 | author1 = Brash | first1 = A. R. | title = Discovery of a second 15S-lipoxygenase in humans | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 94 | issue = 12 | pages = 6148–52 | last2 = Boeglin | first2 = W. E. | last3 = Chang | first3 = M. S. | bibcode = 1997PNAS...94.6148B | doi=10.1073/pnas.94.12.6148}}</ref>
'''15-Lipooxygenase-2''': Cells also used 15-lipoxygenase 2 (i.e. 15-LOX-2 or [[ALOX15B]]) to make 15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE. However this enzyme has a preference for metabolizing [[linoleic acid]] rather than arachidonic acid. It therefore forms linoleic acid metabolites (e.g. [[13-Hydroxyoctadecadienoic acid|13-hydoxyperoxy/hydroxy-octadecadienoic]] and [[9-Hydroxyoctadecadienoic acid|9-hydroperoxy/hydroxyl-octadecadienoic acids]]) in greater amounts than 15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE. 15-LOX-2 also differs from 15-LOX-1 in that it does not make 12(''S'')-HpETE or the leukotriene A<sub>4</sub> isomer cited above.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
'''Cycloxygenase''': Cells can use [[prostaglandin-endoperoxide synthase 1]] (i.e. cyclooxygenenase-1 or COX-1) and [[Prostaglandin-endoperoxide synthase 2]] (COX-2) to metabolize arachidonic acid primarily to [[prostaglandins]] but also to small amounts of '''11(''R'')-HETE''' and a racemic mixture of 15-HETEs composed of ~22% 15(''R'')-HETE and ~78% 15(''S'')-HETE.<ref name="J. lipid Res. 51:575-585, 2010">{{cite journal | pmid = 19752399 | pmc = 2817587 | year = 2010 | author1 = Mulugeta | first1 = S | title = Identification and absolute configuration of dihydroxy-arachidonic acids formed by oxygenation of 5S-HETE by native and aspirin-acetylated COX-2 | journal = The Journal of Lipid Research | volume = 51 | issue = 3 | pages = 575–85 | last2 = Suzuki | first2 = T | last3 = Hernandez | first3 = N. T. | last4 = Griesser | first4 = M | last5 = Boeglin | first5 = W. E. | last6 = Schneider | first6 = C | doi = 10.1194/jlr.M001719 }}</ref> When pretreated with [[aspirin]], however, COX-1 is inactive while COX-2 attacks arachidonic acid to produce almost exclusively 15(''R'')-HETE along with its presumed precursor 15(''R'')-HpETE.<ref name="J. lipid Res. 51:575-585, 2010"/><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10086190 | year = 1999 | author1 = Serhan | first1 = C. N. | title = Aspirin-triggered 15-epi-lipoxin A4 and stable analogs on lipoxin A4 are potent inhibitors of acute inflammation. Receptors and pathways | journal = Advances in Experimental Medicine and Biology | volume = 447 | pages = 133–49 | last2 = Takano | first2 = T | last3 = Maddox | first3 = J. F. | doi = 10.1007/978-1-4615-4861-4_13 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10692466 | year = 2000 | author1 = Rowlinson | first1 = S. W. | title = Spatial requirements for 15-(R)-hydroxy-5Z,8Z,11Z, 13E-eicosatetraenoic acid synthesis within the cyclooxygenase active site of murine COX-2. Why acetylated COX-1 does not synthesize 15-(R)-hete | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 275 | issue = 9 | pages = 6586–91 | last2 = Crews | first2 = B. C. | last3 = Goodwin | first3 = D. C. | last4 = Schneider | first4 = C | last5 = Gierse | first5 = J. K. | last6 = Marnett | first6 = L. J. | doi=10.1074/jbc.275.9.6586}}</ref>
'''Microsome metabolism''': Human and rat microsomal [[cytochrome P450]]s, e.g. CYP2C19, metabolize arachidonic acid to a [[racemic mixture]] of 15-HETEs, i.e., 15(''R'',''S'')-HETEs, >90% of which is the 15(''R'') stereoisomer.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 8443245 | year = 1993 | author1 = Oliw | first1 = E. H. | title = Bis-Allylic hydroxylation of linoleic acid and arachidonic acid by human hepatic monooxygenases | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1166 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 258–63 | doi=10.1016/0005-2760(93)90106-j}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 9435160 | year = 1998 | author1 = Bylund | first1 = J | title = Cytochromes P450 with bisallylic hydroxylation activity on arachidonic and linoleic acids studied with human recombinant enzymes and with human and rat liver microsomes | journal = The Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics | volume = 284 | issue = 1 | pages = 51–60 | last2 = Kunz | first2 = T | last3 = Valmsen | first3 = K | last4 = Oliw | first4 = E. H. }}</ref>
'''Autoxidation''': The spontaneous and non-enzymatically-induced [[autoxidation]] of arachidonic acid yields 15(''R'',''S'')-hydroperoxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',11''Z'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acids. This non-enzymatic reaction is promoted in cells undergoing [[oxidative stress]]. Cells forming this [[racemic mixture]] of 15-hydroperoxy products may convert then to 15(''R,S'')-HETEs and other products. However, the uncontrolled overproduction of the 15-hydroperoxy products may react with other elements to produce cell injury.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0090-6980(80)90156-2|pmid=7384539 |journal=Prostaglandins |volume=19|issue=1 |pages=87–97|year= 1980|title=Preparation and characterization of hydroperoxy-eicosatetraenoic acids (HPETEs) |first1=J. M.|last1= Boeynaems|first2= J. A. |last2=Oates|first3= W. C. |last3=Hubbard }}</ref><ref>Am. J. Pathol. 104:5-62, 1981</ref>
== Further metabolism == The newly formed products formed by the pathways cited in the previous section are bioactive but may also flow into down-stream pathways to form other metabolites with a different sets of bioactivity. The initially formed 15(''S'')-HpETE may be further metabolized by its parent cell or pass it to nearby cell by a process termed [[eicosanoid#Peroxidation and reactive oxygen species|transcellular metabolism]].
15(''S'')-HpETE may be: *Rapidly reduced to 15(''S'')-HETE by ubiquitous cellular [[peroxidase]] reactions including those possessed by [[prostaglandin-endoperoxide synthase]]-1 and -2,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0003-9861(88)90246-9|pmid=3140729|year=1988|pages=162–170|title=Prostaglandin H synthase: Distinct binding sites for cyclooxygenase and peroxidase substrates|journal=Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics|volume=266|issue=1|last1=Marshall|first1=Paul J.|last2=Kulmacz|first2=Richard J.}}</ref> [[prostacyclin synthase]], [[thromboxane synthase]],<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17459323 | pmc = 2041921 | year = 2007 | author1 = Yeh | first1 = H. C. | title = Reaction mechanisms of 15-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid catalyzed by human prostacyclin and thromboxane synthases | journal = Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics | volume = 461 | issue = 2 | pages = 159–68 | last2 = Tsai | first2 = A. L. | last3 = Wang | first3 = L. H. | doi = 10.1016/j.abb.2007.03.012 }}</ref> and vaious[[glutathione peroxidase]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 1314541 | year = 1992 | author1 = Ochi | first1 = H | title = Roles of glutathione and glutathione peroxidase in the protection against endothelial cell injury induced by 15-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid | journal = Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics | volume = 294 | issue = 2 | pages = 407–11 | last2 = Morita | first2 = I | last3 = Murota | first3 = S | doi=10.1016/0003-9861(92)90704-z}}</ref> *[[Acylated]] into membrane [[phospholipid]]s, particularly [[Phosphatidylinositol]]s<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal | pmid = 2117277 | pmc = 54510 | year = 1990 | author1 = Brezinski | first1 = M. E. | title = Selective incorporation of (15S)-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid in phosphatidylinositol of human neutrophils: Agonist-induced deacylation and transformation of stored hydroxyeicosanoids | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 87 | issue = 16 | pages = 6248–52 | last2 = Serhan | first2 = C. N. | doi=10.1073/pnas.87.16.6248| bibcode = 1990PNAS...87.6248B }}</ref><ref name="J. Biol. CheM. 266;7570-7577, 1991">{{cite journal | pmid = 1850411 | year = 1991 | author1 = Legrand | first1 = A. B. | title = Substitution of 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid in the phosphoinositide signaling pathway | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 266 | issue = 12 | pages = 7570–7 | last2 = Lawson | first2 = J. A. | last3 = Meyrick | first3 = B. O. | last4 = Blair | first4 = I. A. | last5 = Oates | first5 = J. A. }}</ref> and [[phosphatidylethanolamine]].<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal | pmid = 3662534 | year = 1987 | author1 = Bergholte | first1 = J. M. | title = Oxidation of 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid and other hydroxy fatty acids by lung prostaglandin dehydrogenase | journal = Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics | volume = 257 | issue = 2 | pages = 444–50 | last2 = Soberman | first2 = R. J. | last3 = Hayes | first3 = R | last4 = Murphy | first4 = R. C. | last5 = Okita | first5 = R. T. | doi=10.1016/0003-9861(87)90589-3}}</ref><ref name="J. Biol. Chem. 287:41651-41666, 2012">{{cite journal | pmid = 23060450 | pmc = 3516716 | year = 2012 | author1 = Hammond | first1 = V. J. | title = Novel keto-phospholipids are generated by monocytes and macrophages, detected in cystic fibrosis, and activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 287 | issue = 50 | pages = 41651–66 | last2 = Morgan | first2 = A. H. | last3 = Lauder | first3 = S | last4 = Thomas | first4 = C. P. | last5 = Brown | first5 = S | last6 = Freeman | first6 = B. A. | last7 = Lloyd | first7 = C. M. | last8 = Davies | first8 = J | last9 = Bush | first9 = A | last10 = Levonen | first10 = A. L. | last11 = Kansanen | first11 = E | last12 = Villacorta | first12 = L | last13 = Chen | first13 = Y. E. | last14 = Porter | first14 = N | last15 = Garcia-Diaz | first15 = Y. M. | last16 = Schopfer | first16 = F. J. | last17 = O'Donnell | first17 = V. B. | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M112.405407 }}</ref> The 15(S)-HpETE is bound primarily at the ''sn''-2 position of these phospholipids (see [[Phospholipase]]) and may be reduced to 15(''S'')-HETE<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="J. Biol. CheM. 266;7570-7577, 1991"/><ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref name="J. Biol. Chem. 287:41651-41666, 2012" /> thereby forming their 15(''S'')-HETE-bound phospholipoid analogs. Phosphotidylinositol phospholipids with 15(''S'')-HETE in the ''sn''-2 position can be attacked by [[phospholipase C]] to form corresponding [[diglyceride]]s with 15(''S'')-HETE at their''sn''-2 positions.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10484452 | year = 1999 | author1 = Alpert | first1 = S. E. | title = 15-HETE-substituted diglycerides selectively regulate PKC isotypes in human tracheal epithelial cells | journal = The American Journal of Physiology | volume = 277 | issue = 3 Pt 1 | pages = L457–64 | last2 = Walenga | first2 = R. W. | last3 = Mandal | first3 = A | last4 = Bourbon | first4 = N | last5 = Kester | first5 = M }}</ref> *Metabolized by 15-LO-1 to its 14,15-''trans''-epoxide, 14,15-trans-epoxide oxido-5''Z'',8''Z'',10''E'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid (i.e., [[Eoxin]] A<sub>4</sub> or EXA<sub>4</sub>), and thereafter to 14(R)-glutothionyl-15(S)hydroxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',10''E'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid (i.e. Eoxin C<sub>4</sub> or EXC<sub>4</sub>) by [[leukotriene C4 synthase]].<ref name="Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 105:680-685, 2008">{{cite journal | pmid = 18184802 | pmc = 2206596 | year = 2008 | author1 = Feltenmark | first1 = S | title = Eoxins are proinflammatory arachidonic acid metabolites produced via the 15-lipoxygenase-1 pathway in human eosinophils and mast cells | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 105 | issue = 2 | pages = 680–5 | last2 = Gautam | first2 = N | last3 = Brunnström | first3 = A | last4 = Griffiths | first4 = W | last5 = Backman | first5 = L | last6 = Edenius | first6 = C | last7 = Lindbom | first7 = L | last8 = Björkholm | first8 = M | last9 = Claesson | first9 = H. E. | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0710127105 | bibcode = 2008PNAS..105..680F }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19130894 | year = 2009 | author1 = Claesson | first1 = H. E. | title = On the biosynthesis and biological role of eoxins and 15-lipoxygenase-1 in airway inflammation and Hodgkin lymphoma | journal = Prostaglandins & Other Lipid Mediators | volume = 89 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 120–5 | doi = 10.1016/j.prostaglandins.2008.12.003 }}</ref><ref name="J. Allegy Clin. Immunol 126:859-867, 2010">{{cite journal | pmid = 20920774 | year = 2010 | author1 = Sachs-Olsen | first1 = C | title = Eoxins: A new inflammatory pathway in childhood asthma | journal = Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology | volume = 126 | issue = 4 | pages = 859–867.e9 | last2 = Sanak | first2 = M | last3 = Lang | first3 = A. M. | last4 = Gielicz | first4 = A | last5 = Mowinckel | first5 = P | last6 = Lødrup Carlsen | first6 = K. C. | last7 = Carlsen | first7 = K. H. | last8 = Szczeklik | first8 = A | doi = 10.1016/j.jaci.2010.07.015 }}</ref> EXC<sub>4</sub> contains [[glutathione]] (i.e. γ-L-glutamyl-L-cysteinylglycine) bound in the ''R'' configuration to carbon 14. EXC<sub>4</sub> is further metabolized by removal of the γ-L-glutamyl residue to form EXD<sub>4</sub> which is in turn further metabolized by removal of the glycine residue to form EXE<sub>4</sub>.<ref name="Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 105:680-685, 2008"/> These metabolic transformations are similar to those in the pathway that metabolizes arachidonic acid to [[LTA<sub>4</sub>]], [[LTC<sub>4</sub>]], [[LTD<sub>4</sub>]], and [[LTE<sub>4</sub>]] and presumed to be conducted by the same enzymes <ref name="Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 105:680-685, 2008" /><ref name="J. Allegy Clin. Immunol 126:859-867, 2010" /><ref>Prostaglandins; see [[Eoxin]]). {{cite journal | pmid = 19130894 | year = 2009 | author1 = Claesson | first1 = H. E. | title = On the biosynthesis and biological role of eoxins and 15-lipoxygenase-1 in airway inflammation and Hodgkin lymphoma | journal = Prostaglandins & Other Lipid Mediators | volume = 89 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 120–5 | doi = 10.1016/j.prostaglandins.2008.12.003 }}</ref> (Eoxins are also termed 14,15-leukotrienes or 14,15-LTs). *Metabolized alternatively by 15-LO-1 to various 8,15-diHETEs including the two 8(R) and 8(S) [[Diastereomer]]s of 8,15(''S'')-dihydroxy-5,9,11,13-eicosatetraenoic acid (8,15-leukotrienes B4) and to two isomeric [[erythro]]-14,15-dihydroxy-5-cis-8,10,12-eicosatetraenoic acids (14,15-leukotrienes B4).<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 7247953 | year = 1981 | author1 = Jubiz | first1 = W | title = Novel leukotrienes: Products formed by initial oxygenation of arachidonic acid at C-15 | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 99 | issue = 3 | pages = 976–86 | last2 = Rådmark | first2 = O | last3 = Lindgren | first3 = J. A. | last4 = Malmsten | first4 = C | last5 = Samuelsson | first5 = B | doi=10.1016/0006-291x(81)91258-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 6272308 | pmc = 348778 | year = 1981 | author1 = Maas | first1 = R. 15(''S'')-HETE may be: *[[Oxidized]] to its [[Ketone|keto]] analog, 15-oxo-ETE, by the same enzyme that converts [[prostaglandins]] of the A, E, and F series to their 15-keto analogs viz., NAD<sup>+</sup>-dependent [[15-hydroxyprostaglandin dehydrogenase]]; 15-oxo-ETE, similar to 15(S)-HETE, may be acylated into membrane phosphatidylethanolamaine<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref name="J. Biol. Chem. 287:41651-41666, 2012" /> or, similar to 15(''S'')-HpETE, conjugated with [[glutathione]] to form a 13-cysteinyl-glycyl-glutamine adduct viz., 13-glutatione,15-oxo-5(''S''),8(''Z''),11(''E'')-eicosatrienoic acid; the latter metabolite is attacked by γ-glutamyl-transferase to form 13-cysteinyl-glycine,15-oxo-5(''S''),8(''Z''),11(''E'')-eicosatrienoic acid.<ref name="Chem. Res 1675">{{cite journal | pmid = 17910482 | year = 2007 | author1 = Lee | first1 = S. A. | doi = 10.1021/tx700130p }}</ref> *Acylated into membrane [[phospholipid]]s, particularly [[phosphatidylinositol]] and [[phosphatidylethanolamine]]. Phospholipid products contain this 15(''S'')-HETE most likely at the ''sn''-2 position. 15(''S'')-HETE-containing-phospholipids may also be made directly by the action of 15-LO-1 on membrane phosphatidylinositols or phosphatidylethanolamines containing arachidonic acid at the ''sn''-2 positions.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 9414270 | year = 1998 | author1 = Brinckmann | first1 = R | title = Membrane translocation of 15-lipoxygenase in hematopoietic cells is calcium-dependent and activates the oxygenase activity of the enzyme | journal = Blood | volume = 91 | issue = 1 | pages = 64–74 | last2 = Schnurr | first2 = K | last3 = Heydeck | first3 = D | last4 = Rosenbach | first4 = T | last5 = Kolde | first5 = G | last6 = Kühn | first6 = H }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17519227 | year = 2007 | author1 = Maskrey | first1 = B. Chem. 287:41651-41666, 2012" /> *Oxygenated by 5-lipoxygenase ([[ALOX5]] to form its 5,6-trans epoxide derivative which may then rearrange to the [[lipoxin]]s (LX), LXA<sub>4</sub> (i.e. 5(''S''),6(''R''),15(''S'')-trihydroxy-7''E'',9''E'',11''Z'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid) and LXB<sub>4</sub> (i.e., 5(''S''),14(''R''),15(''S'')-trihydroxy-6''E'',8''Z'',10''E'',12''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid).<ref name="Prostaglandins Leukot Essent Fatty Acids 73:141-162, 2005">{{cite journal | pmid = 16005201 | year = 2005 | author1 = Serhan | first1 = C. The latter two metabolites may also be made by 15-LO's metabolism of [[5-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid]] (i.e. 5-HETE) and [[5-oxo-eicosatetraenoic acid]]) (i.e. 5-oxo-ETE), respectively.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 2546590 | year = 1989 | author1 = Serhan | first1 = C. 15(''R'')-HpETE may be: *Reduced to 15(''R'')-HETE by the same pathway that reduces 5(''S'')-HpETE to 15(''S'')-HETE.<ref name="J. Biol. Chem. 280:28337-28346, 2005" /> *Similar to 15(''S'')-HpETE, subject to decomposition to form various bifuctional potentially toxic electrophiles such as 4-hydroxy-2(''E'')-nonenal and 4-oxo-2(''E'')-nonenal.<ref name="J. Biol. Chem. 280:28337-28346, 2005" />
15(''R'')-HETE may be: *Similar to 15(''S'')-HETE, oxidized by NAD-dependent 5-hydroxyprostaglandin dehydrogenase to form 15-oxo-ETE which product can be converted its 13-cysteinyl-glycyl-glutamyl and then 13-cysteinyl-glycine products as described above for 5(''S'')-HETE.<ref name="Chem. Res 1675"/> *Similar to 15(''S'')-HETE, oxygenated by ALOX5 to form its 5,6-oxido derivative which then rearranges to the 15(''R'') [[diastereomers]] of LXA<sub>4</sub> and (LXB<sub>4</sub> viz., 15-epic LXA<sub>4</sub> 5(''S''),6(''R''),15(''R'')-trihydroxy-7''E'',9''E'',11''Z'',13''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid) and 15-epi-LXB<sub>4</sub> (i.e., 5(''S''),14(''R''),15(''S'')-trihydroxy-''6''E,8''Z'',10''E'',12''E''-eicosatetraenoic acid, respectively.<ref name="Prostaglandins Leukot Essent Fatty Acids 73:141-162, 2005" /><ref name="resolve" />
== Activities == === 15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE === Most studies have analyzed the action of 15(''S'')-HETE but not that of its less stable precursor 15(''S'')-HpETE. Since this precursor is rapidly converted to 15(''S'')-HETE in cells, it is likely that the two metabolites share similar activities. In many studies, however, is not clear that these activities reflect their intrinsic action or reflect their conversion to the metabolites sited above.
15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE bind to and activate the [[G protein-coupled receptor]], [[Leukotriene B4 receptor 2]], i.e. BLT2.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11278893 | year = 2001 | author1 = Yokomizo | first1 = T | title = Hydroxyeicosanoids bind to and activate the low affinity leukotriene B4 receptor, BLT2 | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 276 | issue = 15 | pages = 12454–9 | last2 = Kato | first2 = K | last3 = Hagiya | first3 = H | last4 = Izumi | first4 = T | last5 = Shimizu | first5 = T | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M011361200 }}</ref> This receptor activation may mediate, at least in part, certain cell-stimulating activities of the two metabolites. BLT2 may be responsible in part or whole for mediating the growth-promoting and anti-[[apoptosis]] (i.e. anti-cell death) activities of 15(S)-HETE in cultured human breast cancer cells;<ref name="PLoS One. 2013 May 2;8(5):e63076. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0063076" >{{cite journal | pmid = 23658799 | pmc = 3642080 | year = 2013 | author1 = O'Flaherty | first1 = J. T. | title = Fatty acid metabolites in rapidly proliferating breast cancer | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 8 | issue = 5 | pages = e63076 | last2 = Wooten | first2 = R. A. | last8 = Edwards | first8 = I. J. | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0063076 | bibcode = 2013PLoSO...863076O }}</ref> human cancer colon cells,<ref name="Int. J. J. | doi = 10.1016/j.biocel.2013.05.009 }}</ref> and the excess [[fibrosis]] that causes the narrowing of pulmonary arteries in hypoxia-induced [[pulmonary hypertension]]<ref name="J. Lipid Res. 47:2681-2689"/> or narrowing of portal arteries in the [[portal hypertension]] accompanying liver cirrosis.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25347188 | pmc = 4210132 | year = 2014 | author1 = Pandey | first1 = V | title = Comparative analysis and modeling of the severity of steatohepatitis in DDC-treated mouse strains | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 9 | issue = 10 | pages = e111006 | last2 = Sultan | first2 = M | last3 = Kashofer | first3 = K | last4 = Ralser | first4 = M | last5 = Amstislavskiy | first5 = V | last6 = Starmann | first6 = J | last7 = Osprian | first7 = I | last8 = Grimm | first8 = C | last9 = Hache | first9 = H | last10 = Yaspo | first10 = M. L. | last11 = Sültmann | first11 = H | last12 = Trauner | first12 = M | last13 = Denk | first13 = H | last14 = Zatloukal | first14 = K | last15 = Lehrach | first15 = H | last16 = Wierling | first16 = C | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0111006 | bibcode = 2014PLoSO...9k1006P }}</ref> 15(''S'')-HETE may also act through BLT2 to stimulate an immediate contractile response in rat pulmonary arteries<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20139061 | year = 2010 | author1 = Wang | first1 = Y | title = Role of the G-protein and tyrosine kinase--Rho/ROK pathways in 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid induced pulmonary vasoconstriction in hypoxic rats | journal = Journal of Biochemistry | volume = 147 | issue = 5 | pages = 751–64 | last2 = Liang | first2 = D | last3 = Wang | first3 = S | last4 = Qiu | first4 = Z | last5 = Chu | first5 = X | last6 = Chen | first6 = S | last7 = Li | first7 = L | last8 = Nie | first8 = X | last9 = Zhang | first9 = R | last10 = Wang | first10 = Z | last11 = Zhu | first11 = D | doi = 10.1093/jb/mvq010 }}</ref> and its [[Angiogenesis|angiogenic]] effect on human umbilical<ref name="Inflamm. Res. 61:707-718, 2012"/> and dermal<ref name="diction" /> vascular endothelial cells.
15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE also directly bind with and activate [[peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma]].<ref name="Mol. Pharmacol. 77:171-184, 2010">{{cite journal | pmid = 19903832 | year = 2010 | author1 = Naruhn | first1 = S | title = 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid is a preferential peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor beta/delta agonist | journal = Molecular Pharmacology | volume = 77 | issue = 2 | pages = 171–84 | last2 = Meissner | first2 = W | last3 = Adhikary | first3 = T | last4 = Kaddatz | first4 = K | last5 = Klein | first5 = T | last6 = Watzer | first6 = B | last7 = Müller-Brüsselbach | first7 = S | last8 = Müller | first8 = R | doi = 10.1124/mol.109.060541 }}</ref> This activation may contribute to the ability of 15(S)-HETE to inhibit the growth of cultured human prostate cancer [[PC-3]], [[LNCaP]], and [[DU145]] cell lines and non-malignant human prostate cells;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11212240 | year = 2001 | author1 = Shappell | first1 = S. B. | title = 15S-Hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma and inhibits proliferation in PC3 prostate carcinoma cells | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 61 | issue = 2 | pages = 497–503 | last2 = Gupta | first2 = R. A. | last3 = Manning | first3 = S | last4 = Whitehead | first4 = R | last5 = Boeglin | first5 = W. E. | last6 = Schneider | first6 = C | last7 = Case | first7 = T | last8 = Price | first8 = J | last9 = Jack | first9 = G. S. | last10 = Wheeler | first10 = T. M. | last11 = Matusik | first11 = R. J. | last12 = Brash | first12 = A. R. | last13 = Dubois | first13 = R. N. }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11839751 | year = 2002 | author1 = Tang | first1 = S | title = Evidence that arachidonate 15-lipoxygenase 2 is a negative cell cycle regulator in normal prostate epithelial cells | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 277 | issue = 18 | pages = 16189–201 | last2 = Bhatia | first2 = B | last3 = Maldonado | first3 = C. J. | last4 = Yang | first4 = P | last5 = Newman | first5 = R. A. | last6 = Liu | first6 = J | last7 = Chandra | first7 = D | last8 = Traag | first8 = J | last9 = Klein | first9 = R. D. | last10 = Fischer | first10 = S. M. | last11 = Chopra | first11 = D | last12 = Shen | first12 = J | last13 = Zhau | first13 = H. E. | last14 = Chung | first14 = L. W. | last15 = Tang | first15 = D. G. | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M111936200 }}</ref> lung adenocarcinoma [[A549 cell]]s;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12387716 | year = 2002 | author1 = Kudryavtsev | first1 = I. A. | title = Arachidonic acid metabolism in growth control of A549 human lung adenocarcinoma cells | journal = Biochemistry. Biokhimiia | volume = 67 | issue = 9 | pages = 1021–6 | last2 = Golenko | first2 = O. D. | last3 = Gudkova | first3 = M. V. | last4 = Myasishcheva | first4 = N. V. }}</ref> human colorectal cancer cells;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 14566836 | year = 2003 | author1 = Chen | first1 = G. G. | title = 15-hydroxy-eicosatetraenoic acid arrests growth of colorectal cancer cells via a peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma-dependent pathway | journal = International Journal of Cancer | volume = 107 | issue = 5 | pages = 837–43 | last2 = Xu | first2 = H | last3 = Lee | first3 = J. F. | last4 = Subramaniam | first4 = M | last5 = Leung | first5 = K. L. | last6 = Wang | first6 = S. H. | last7 = Chan | first7 = U. P. | last8 = Spelsberg | first8 = T. C. | doi = 10.1002/ijc.11447 }}</ref> corneal epithelial cells;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15728540 | year = 2005 | author1 = Chang | first1 = M. S. | title = Detection and subcellular localization of two 15S-lipoxygenases in human cornea | journal = Investigative Ophthalmology & Visual Science | volume = 46 | issue = 3 | pages = 849–56 | last2 = Schneider | first2 = C | last3 = Roberts | first3 = R. L. | last4 = Shappell | first4 = S. B. | last5 = Haselton | first5 = F. R. | last6 = Boeglin | first6 = W. E. | last7 = Brash | first7 = A. R. | doi = 10.1167/iovs.04-1166 }}</ref> and [[Jurkat]] T-cell leukemia cells.<ref name="appropo">{{cite journal | pmid = 18494609 | year = 2009 | author1 = Kumar | first1 = K. A. | title = Effects of (15S)-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid and (15S)-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid on the acute- lymphoblastic-leukaemia cell line Jurkat: Activation of the Fas-mediated death pathway | journal = Biotechnology and Applied Biochemistry | volume = 52 | issue = Pt 2 | pages = 121–33 | last2 = Arunasree | first2 = K. M. | last3 = Roy | first3 = K. R. | last4 = Reddy | first4 = N. P. | last5 = Aparna | first5 = A | last6 = Reddy | first6 = G. V. | last7 = Reddanna | first7 = P | doi = 10.1042/BA20070264 }}</ref> The decline in the level of 15(''S'')-HpETE-forming enzymes and consequential fall in cellular 15-HETE production that occurs in human prostate cancer cells may be one mechanism by which this and perhaps other human cancer cells (e.g. those of the colon, rectum, and lung) avoid the apoptosis-inducing actions of 15(''S'')-HpETE and/or 15(''S'')-HETE and thereby proliferate and spread.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10393855 | pmc = 1866677 | year = 1999 | author1 = Shappell | first1 = S. B. | title = 15-lipoxygenase-2 (15-LOX-2) is expressed in benign prostatic epithelium and reduced in prostate adenocarcinoma | journal = The American Journal of Pathology | volume = 155 | issue = 1 | pages = 235–45 | last2 = Boeglin | first2 = W. E. | last3 = Olson | first3 = S. J. | last4 = Kasper | first4 = S | last5 = Brash | first5 = A. R. | doi = 10.1016/S0002-9440(10)65117-6 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17164141 | year = 2007 | author1 = Tang | first1 = D. G. | title = 15-lipoxygenase 2 (15-LOX2) is a functional tumor suppressor that regulates human prostate epithelial cell differentiation, senescence, and growth (size) | journal = Prostaglandins & Other Lipid Mediators | volume = 82 | issue = 1–4 | pages = 135–46 | last2 = Bhatia | first2 = B | last3 = Tang | first3 = S | last4 = Schneider-Broussard | first4 = R | doi = 10.1016/j.prostaglandins.2006.05.022 }}</ref> In this scenario, 15(S)-HETE and one of its formaing enzymes, particularly 15-LOX-2, appear to act as tumor suppressors.
Some of the inhibitory effects of 15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE, particularly when induced by high concentrations (e.g. >1-10 micromolar), may be due to a less specific mechanism: 15(''S'')-HpETE and to a lesser extent 15(''S'')-HETE induce the generation of [[Reactive oxygen species]]. These species trigger cells to activate their death programs, i.e. [[apoptosis]], and/or are openly toxic to the cells.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 1520701 | year = 1992 | author1 = Ochi | first1 = H | title = Mechanism for endothelial cell injury induced by 15-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid, an arachidonate lipoxygenase product | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1136 | issue = 3 | pages = 247–52 | last2 = Morita | first2 = I | last3 = Murota | first3 = S | doi=10.1016/0167-4889(92)90113-p}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10833416 | year = 2000 | author1 = MacCarrone | first1 = M | title = Activation of different lipoxygenase isozymes induces apoptosis in human erythroleukemia and neuroblastoma cells | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 272 | issue = 2 | pages = 345–50 | last2 = Ranalli | first2 = M | last3 = Bellincampi | first3 = L | last4 = Salucci | first4 = M. L. | last5 = Sabatini | first5 = S | last6 = Melino | first6 = G | last7 = Finazzi-Agrò | first7 = A | doi = 10.1006/bbrc.2000.2597 }}</ref><ref name="appropo" /><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19949744 | year = 2009 | author1 = Dymkowska | first1 = D | title = Arachidonic acid-induced apoptosis in rat hepatoma AS-30D cells is mediated by reactive oxygen species | journal = Acta Biochimica Polonica | volume = 56 | issue = 4 | pages = 711–5 | last2 = Wojtczak | first2 = L }}</ref><ref>Cells. 32:1021-1027, 2011</ref> 15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(S)-HETE inhibit angiogenesis and the growth of cultured human chronic myelogenous leukemia K-562 cells by a mechanism that is associated with the production of reactive oxygen species.<ref name="Inflamm. Res. 61:707-718, 2012"/><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 25346880 | pmc = 4207198 | year = 2014 | author1 = Soumya | first1 = S. J. | title = 15-LOX metabolites and angiogenesis: Angiostatic effect of 15(S)-HPETE involves induction of apoptosis in adipose endothelial cells | journal = PeerJ | volume = 2 | pages = e635 | last2 = Binu | first2 = S | last3 = Helen | first3 = A | last4 = Reddanna | first4 = P | last5 = Sudhakaran | first5 = P. R. | doi = 10.7717/peerj.635 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17517376 | year = 2007 | author1 = Mahipal | first1 = S. V. | title = Effect of 15-lipoxygenase metabolites, 15-(S)-HPETE and 15-(S)-HETE on chronic myelogenous leukemia cell line K-562: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) mediate caspase-dependent apoptosis | journal = Biochemical Pharmacology | volume = 74 | issue = 2 | pages = 202–14 | last2 = Subhashini | first2 = J | last3 = Reddy | first3 = M. C. | last4 = Reddy | first4 = M. M. | last5 = Anilkumar | first5 = K | last6 = Roy | first6 = K. R. | last7 = Reddy | first7 = G. V. | last8 = Reddanna | first8 = P | doi = 10.1016/j.bcp.2007.04.005 }}</ref>
Several bifuctional electrophilic breakdown products of 15(''S'')-HpETE, e.g. 4-hydroxy-2(''E'')-nonenal, 4-hydroperoxy-2(''E'')-nonenal, 4-oxo-2(''E'')-nonenal, and ''cis''-4,5-epoxy-2(''E'')-decanal, are [[mutagens]] in mammalian cells and thereby may contripute to the development and/or progression of human cancers.<ref name="J. Biol. Chem. 280:28337-28346, 2005" />
=== 15(''R'')-HETE === Similar to 15(''S'')-HpETE and 15(''S'')-HETE and with similar potency, 15(''R'')-HETE binds with and activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma.<ref name="Mol. Pharmacol. 77:171-184, 2010"/> The precursor of 15(''R'')-HETE, 15(''R'')-HpETE may, similar to 15(''S'')-HpETE, break down to the mutagenic products 4-hydroxy-2(''E'')-nonenal, 4-hydroperoxy-2(''E'')-nonenal, 4-oxo-2(''E'')-nonenal, and ''cis''-4,5-epoxy-2(''E'')-decanal and therefore be involved in cancer development and/or progression.<ref name="J. Biol. Chem. 280:28337-28346, 2005"/>
=== 15-oxo-ETE === In cultured human monocytes of the [[THP1 cell line]], 15-oxo-ETE inactivates IKKβ (also known as [[IKK2]]) thereby blocking this cell's [[NF-κB]]-mediated pro-inflammatory responses (e.g.,. [[Lipopolysaccharide]]-induced production of [[TNFα]], [[Interleukin 6]], and [[IL1B]]) while concurrently activating anti-oxidant responses upregulated through the anti-oxidant response element (ARE) by forcing cytosolic [[KEAP1]] to release [[NFE2L2]] which then moves to the nucleus, binds ARE, and induces production of, e.g. hemoxygenase-1, NADPH-quinone oxidoreductase, and possibly glutamate-cysteine ligase modifier.<ref name="dx.doi.org">{{cite journal | pmid = 25450232 | pmc = 4414684 | year = 2015 | author1 = Snyder | first1 = N. W. | title = 15-Oxoeicosatetraenoic acid is a 15-hydroxyprostaglandin dehydrogenase-derived electrophilic mediator of inflammatory signaling pathways | journal = Chemico-Biological Interactions | volume = 234 | pages = 144–53 | last2 = Golin-Bisello | first2 = F | last3 = Gao | first3 = Y | last4 = Blair | first4 = I. A. | last5 = Freeman | first5 = B. A. | last6 = Wendell | first6 = S. G. | doi = 10.1016/j.cbi.2014.10.029 }}</ref> By these actions, 15-oxo-ETE may dampen inflammatory and/or [[Oxidative stress]] responses. In a cell-free system, 15-oxo-ETE is a moderately potent (IC<sub>50</sub>=1 μM) inhibitor of [[12-lipoxygenase]] but not other human lipoxygenases.<ref name="Bioorg. Med. Chem. 22:4293–4297">{{cite journal | pmid = 24924423 | pmc = 4112157 | year = 2014 | author1 = Armstrong | first1 = M. M. | title = Inhibitory and mechanistic investigations of oxo-lipids with human lipoxygenase isozymes | journal = Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry | volume = 22 | issue = 15 | pages = 4293–7 | last2 = Diaz | first2 = G | last3 = Kenyon | first3 = V | last4 = Holman | first4 = T. R. | doi = 10.1016/j.bmc.2014.05.025 }}</ref> This effect could also have anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects by blocking the formation of [[12-HETE]] and [[Hepoxilin]]s. 15-Oxo-ETE is an example of an α,β unsaturated ketone [[Electrophile]]. These ketones are highly reactive with [[nucleophile]]s, adducting to, for example, the cysteines in transcription and transcription-related regulatory factors and enzymes to form their alkylated and thereby often inactivated products.<ref name="Bioorg. Med. Chem. 22:4293–4297"/><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24161076 | pmc = 4030715 | year = 2014 | author1 = Delmastro-Greenwood | first1 = M | title = Redox-dependent anti-inflammatory signaling actions of unsaturated fatty acids | journal = Annual Review of Physiology | volume = 76 | pages = 79–105 | last2 = Freeman | first2 = B. A. | last3 = Wendell | first3 = S. G. | doi = 10.1146/annurev-physiol-021113-170341 }}</ref> It is presumed that the preceding activities of 15-oxo-ETE reflect its adduction to the indicated elements.<ref name="dx.doi.org"/> 15-Oxo-ETE, at 2-10 μM, also inhibits the proliferation of cultured [[Human umbilical vein endothelial cell]]s and LoVo human colorectal cancer cells <ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19535459 | pmc = 2730384 | year = 2009 | author1 = Wei | first1 = C | title = 15-oxo-Eicosatetraenoic acid, a metabolite of macrophage 15-hydroxyprostaglandin dehydrogenase that inhibits endothelial cell proliferation | journal = Molecular Pharmacology | volume = 76 | issue = 3 | pages = 516–25 | last2 = Zhu | first2 = P | last3 = Shah | first3 = S. J. | last4 = Blair | first4 = I. A. | doi = 10.1124/mol.109.057489 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23945567 | pmc = 3793611 | year = 2013 | author1 = Snyder | first1 = N. W. | title = Cellular uptake and antiproliferative effects of 11-oxo-eicosatetraenoic acid | journal = The Journal of Lipid Research | volume = 54 | issue = 11 | pages = 3070–7 | last2 = Revello | first2 = S. D. | last3 = Liu | first3 = X | last4 = Zhang | first4 = S | last5 = Blair | first5 = I. A. | doi = 10.1194/jlr.M040741 }}</ref> and at the extremely high concentration of 100 μM inhibits the proliferation of cultured MBA-MD-231 and MCF7 breast cancer cells as well as SKOV3 ovarian cancer cells.<ref name="Biophysica Acta 2005">{{cite journal | pmid = 16154383 | year = 2005 | author1 = O'Flaherty | first1 = J. T. | title = 5-Oxo-ETE analogs and the proliferation of cancer cells | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids | volume = 1736 | issue = 3 | pages = 228–36 | last2 = Rogers | first2 = L. C. | last3 = Paumi | first3 = C. M. | last4 = Hantgan | first4 = R. R. | last5 = Thomas | first5 = L. R. | last6 = Clay | first6 = C. E. | last7 = High | first7 = K | last8 = Chen | first8 = Y. Q. | last9 = Willingham | first9 = M. C. | last10 = Smitherman | first10 = P. K. | last11 = Kute | first11 = T. E. | last12 = Rao | first12 = A | last13 = Cramer | first13 = S. D. | last14 = Morrow | first14 = C. S. | doi = 10.1016/j.bbalip.2005.08.009 }}</ref> They may use a similar "protein-adduction" mechanism; if so the target protein(s) for these effects have not been defined or even suggested. This 15-oxo-ETE action may prove to inhibit the remodeling of blood vessels and reduce the growth of the cited cell types and cancers. At sub-micromolar concentrations, 15-oxo-ETE has weak [[Chemotaxis]] activity for human [[monocyte]]s and could serve to recruit this [[White blood cell]] into [[inflammatory response]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 8906847 | year = 1996 | author1 = Sozzani | first1 = S | title = Stimulating properties of 5-oxo-eicosanoids for human monocytes: Synergism with monocyte chemotactic protein-1 and -3 | journal = Journal of Immunology | volume = 157 | issue = 10 | pages = 4664–71 | last2 = Zhou | first2 = D | last3 = Locati | first3 = M | last4 = Bernasconi | first4 = S | last5 = Luini | first5 = W | last6 = Mantovani | first6 = A | last7 = O'Flaherty | first7 = J. T. }}</ref>
=== 5-Oxo-15(S)-hydroxy-ETE ===
5-Oxo-15(S)-hydroxy-ETE is properly a member of the [[5-HETE]] family of agonists which binds to the [[Oxoeicosanoid receptor 1]], a [[G protein-coupled receptor]], to activate its various target cells. As such, it is a potent stimulator of [[leukocytes]], particularly [[eosinophils]], as well as other OXE1-bearing cells including [[MDA-MB-231]], [[MCF7]], and [[SKOV3]] cancer cells (see [[5-Hydroxyicosatetraenoic acid and 5-oxo-eicosatetraenoic acid]]).<ref> {{cite journal | pmid = 8683135 | year = 1996 | author1 = O'Flaherty | first1 = J. T. | title = 5-Oxo-eicosatetraenoate is a broadly active, eosinophil-selective stimulus for human granulocytes | journal = Journal of Immunology | volume = 157 | issue = 1 | pages = 336–42 | last2 = Kuroki | first2 = M | last3 = Nixon | first3 = A. B. | last4 = Wijkander | first4 = J | last5 = Yee | first5 = E | last6 = Lee | first6 = S. L. | last7 = Smitherman | first7 = P. K. | last8 = Wykle | first8 = R. L. | last9 = Daniel | first9 = L. W. }} </ref> It also binds with and activates [[PPARγ]] and thereby can stimulate or inhibit cells independently of OXE1.<ref name="Biophysica Acta 2005"/>
=== Lipoxins === LXA4, LXB4, AT-LXA4, and AT-LXB4 are [[specialized proresolving mediators]], i.e. they potently inhibit the progression and contribute to the resolution of diverse inflammatory and allergic reactions (see [[specialized proresolving mediators#lipoxins]] and [[Lipoxin]]s).
=== Eoxins === [[Eoxin A4]], [[Eoxin C4]], [[Eoxin D4]], and [[Eoxin E4]] and analogs of [[leukotriene A4]], [[leukotriene C4|C4]], [[leukotriene D4]], and [[leukotriene E4|E4]]. Formation of the leukotrienes is initiated by 5-lipoxygenase metabolism of arachidonic acid to form a 5,6-[[epoxide]] viz, leukotriene A4; the latter metabolite is then converted to C4, D4, and E4 in succession. Formation of the eoxins is initiated by a 15-lipoxyenase-mediated metabolism of arachiconic acid to a 14,15-epoxide, eoxin A4 followed by its serial conversion to epoxins C4, D4, and E4 using the same pathways and enzymes that metabolize leukotriene A4 to its down-stream products. Preliminary studies have found that the eoxins have pro-inflammatory actions, suggest that they are involved in severe asthma, aspirin-induced asthma attacks, and perhaps other allergic reactions. The production of eoxins by Reed-Sternburg cells has also led to suggestion that they are involve in the lymphoma of Hodgkins disease.<ref name="pmid19130894">{{cite journal | vauthors = Claesson HE | title = On the biosynthesis and biological role of eoxins and 15-lipoxygenase-1 in airway inflammation and Hodgkin lymphoma | journal = Prostaglandins & Other Lipid Mediators | volume = 89 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 120–5 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19130894 | doi = 10.1016/j.prostaglandins.2008.12.003 | url = }}</ref> Drugs blocking the 15-lipoxygenases may be useful for inhibiting inflammation by reducing the production of the eoxins.<ref name="pmid26560362">{{cite journal | vauthors = Sadeghian H, Jabbari A | title = 15-Lipoxygenase inhibitors: a patent review | journal = Expert Opinion on Therapeutic Patents | volume = 26 | issue = 1 | pages = 65–88 | year = 2016 | pmid = 26560362 | doi = 10.1517/13543776.2016.1113259 | url = }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Epi-lipoxins]] * [[eoxins]] * [[Specialized pro-resolving mediators]]

{{Chembox | ImageFile = DAMBDSacid.png | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | IUPACName = 4,4′-Diamino-2,2′-stilbenedisulfonic acid | OtherNames = amsonic acid |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | CASNo = 81-11-8 | PubChem = 11462834 | ChemSpiderID = 4447454 | SMILES = c1cc(c(cc1N)S(=O)(=O)O)/C=C/c2ccc(cc2S(=O)(=O)O)N | StdInChI = 1S/C14H14N2O6S2/c15-11-5-3-9(13(7-11)23(17,18)19)1-2-10-4-6-12(16)8-14(10)24(20,21)22/h1-8H,15-16H2,(H,17,18,19)(H,20,21,22)/b2-1+
| StdInChIKey = REJHVSOVQBJEBF-OWOJBTEDSA-N}} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = |C=14|H=14|N=2|O=6|S=2 | MolarMass = 370.40 | Appearance = white solid | Density = | MeltingPt = | BoilingPt = | Solubility = }} |Section3={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards = | FlashPt = | AutoignitionPt = }} }}
'''4,4′-Diamino-2,2′-stilbenedisulfonic acid''' is the [[organic compound]] with the formula (H<sub>2</sub>NC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>3</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>H)<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>. It is a white, water-soluble solid. Structurally, it is a derivative of trans-[[stilbene]], containing [[amino]] and [[sulfonic acid]] [[functional group]]s on each of the two [[phenyl ring]]s.
The compound is a popular [[optical brightener]] for use in [[laundry detergent]]s.
It is produced by reduction of [[Disodium 4,4'-dinitrostilbene-2,2'-disulfonate|4,4′-dinitro-2,2′-stilbenedisulfonic acid]] with iron powder.<ref name=Ullmann>P. F. Vogt, J. J. Gerulis, "Amines, Aromatic" in ''Ullmann’s Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry'', 2005, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim. {{doi|10.1002/14356007.a02_037}}</ref>
==References== <references />

{{Infobox film | name = All in This Tea | image = All in This Tea.jpg | alt = | director = [[Les Blank]]
[[Gina Leibrecht]] | producer = Les Blank
Gina Leibrecht | narrator = | music = | cinematography = Les Blank | editing = Gina Leibrecht | studio = Flower Films | distributor = Flower Films | released = {{Film date|2007|4|14|Ashland|2008|6|27|United States}} | runtime = 70 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''All in This Tea''''' is a 2007 documentary film co-directed by [[Les Blank]] and Gina Leibrecht, about [[Chinese tea]]. It follows the American [[tea]] [[connoisseur]] [[David Lee Hoffman]] as he travels to remote tea-growing areas of [[China]]. Hoffman attempts to interest Chinese tea growers and distributors in [[fair trade]] issues, and explores the importance of [[terroir]] and [[Organic farming|organic growing methods]] in both the quality and future sustainability of the Chinese tea market.{{cite web|title=All in This Tea (2007)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1015968/plotsummary?ref_=tt_ov_pl|publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=17 October 2013}}{{cite web|title=All In This Tea|url=http://www.allinthistea.com/|publisher=allinthistea.com|accessdate=17 October 2013}}{{cite web|title=All In This Tea (2007)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nNw1PwlNRWk|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=17 October 2013}}{{cite web|title=All in This Tea – DVD Documentary|url=http://www.teaviews.com/2008/01/18/all-in-this-tea-dvd-documentary/|publisher=teaviews.com|accessdate=17 October 2013}} The film premiered at the [[San Francisco International Film Festival]] in 2007.{{Cite web |url=http://fest07.sffs.org/films/film_details.php?id=6 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-10-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009134630/http://fest07.sffs.org/films/film_details.php?id=6 |archive-date=2007-10-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }} It was filmed with a [[hand-held camera]] on [[digital video]] and is 70 minutes in length. ==Production== {{Empty section|date=August 2017}} ==Critical response== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has a rating of 83%, based on 12 reviews, with an average rating of 7/10.{{cite web|title=All in This Tea (2007)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1194403-all_in_this_tea/|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=14 August 2017}} ==See also== *''[[Garlic Is as Good as Ten Mothers]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.allinthistea.com/}} *{{IMDb title|1015968}} *{{Allmovie title|394860}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|1194403_all_in_this_tea}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071009134630/http://fest07.sffs.org/films/film_details.php?id=6 ''All In This Tea''] at San Francisco International Film Festival site {{Les Blank}} {{DEFAULTSORT:All In This Tea}} [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:Chinese tea]] [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Les Blank]] [[Category:Documentary films about agriculture]] [[Category:Works about tea]] [[Category:Films shot in China]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about food and drink]] {{environment-documentary-film-stub}}

revision.comment: avoid piping into a redirect
revision.text:
[[File:MISB ST 0601.8 - Platform Angle of Attack.png|thumb|350px|Platform angle of attack]] [[Image:Airfoil angle of attack.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Angle of attack of an airfoil]]
In [[fluid dynamics]], '''angle of attack''' ('''AOA''', or '''<math>\alpha</math>''') is the [[angle]] between a [[Airfoil#Airfoil terminology|reference line]] on a body (often the [[chord (aircraft)|chord line]] of an [[airfoil]]) and the [[vector (geometry)|vector]] representing the relative motion between the body and the fluid through which it is moving.<ref name="nasa">{{cite web|url=http://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/k-12/airplane/incline.html|title=NASA aeronautics guided tour}}</ref> Angle of attack is the angle between the body's reference line and the oncoming flow. This article focuses on the most common application, the angle of attack of a wing or airfoil moving through air.
In [[aerodynamics]], angle of attack specifies the angle between the chord line of the wing of a [[fixed-wing aircraft]] and the vector representing the relative motion between the aircraft and the atmosphere. Since a wing can have twist, a chord line of the whole wing may not be definable, so an alternate reference line is simply defined. Often, the chord line of the [[Wing root|root of the wing]] is chosen as the reference line. Another choice is to use a horizontal line on the [[fuselage]] as the reference line (and also as the longitudinal axis).<ref>{{cite journal |title=Summary of Methods of Measuring Angle of Attack on Aircraft |url=http://naca.central.cranfield.ac.uk/reports/1958/naca-tn-4351.pdf |issue=NACA-TN-4351 |journal=NACA Technical Note |first=William |last=Gracey |year=1958 |pages=1–30 |publisher=NASA Technical Reports}}</ref> Some authors<ref name="SHIF">John S. Denker, ''See How It Flies''. http://www.av8n.com/how/htm/aoa.html#sec-def-aoa</ref><ref name="SnH">Wolfgang Langewiesche, ''Stick and Rudder: An Explanation of the Art of Flying'', McGraw-Hill Professional, first edition (September 1, 1990), {{ISBN|0-07-036240-8}}</ref> do not use an arbitrary chord line but use the [[zero lift axis]] where, by definition, zero angle of attack corresponds to zero [[Lift coefficient|coefficient of lift]].
Some British authors have used the term [[angle of incidence (aerodynamics)|angle of incidence]] instead of angle of attack.<ref>Langewiesche p. 7</ref> However, this can lead to confusion with the term ''riggers' angle of incidence'' meaning the angle between the chord of an airfoil and some fixed datum in the airplane.<ref>Kermode, A.C. (1972), ''Mechanics of Flight'', Chapter 3 (8th edition), Pitman Publishing Limited, London {{ISBN|0-273-31623-0}}</ref>
==Relation between angle of attack and lift== [[Image:Lift curve.svg|thumb|300px|right|A typical [[lift coefficient]] curve.]] The [[lift coefficient]] of a [[fixed-wing aircraft]] varies with angle of attack. Increasing angle of attack is associated with increasing lift coefficient up to the maximum lift coefficient, after which lift coefficient decreases.<ref name="nasa-lc">{{cite web|url=http://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/k-12/airplane/liftco.html|title=NASA Lift Coefficient}}</ref>
As the angle of attack of a fixed-wing aircraft increases, [[Flow separation|separation]] of the airflow from the upper surface of the wing becomes more pronounced, leading to a reduction in the rate of increase of the lift coefficient. The figure shows a typical curve for a [[Camber (aerodynamics)|cambered]] straight wing. A symmetrical wing has zero lift at 0 degrees angle of attack. The lift curve is also influenced by the wing shape, including its [[airfoil]] section and [[planform (aeronautics)|wing planform]]. A [[swept wing]] has a lower, flatter curve with a higher critical angle.
==Critical angle of attack== The '''critical angle of attack''' is the angle of attack which produces maximum lift coefficient. This is also called the "[[Stall (fluid dynamics)|stall]] angle of attack". Below the critical angle of attack, as the angle of attack increases, the lift coefficient increases. Conversely, above the critical angle of attack, as angle of attack increases, the air begins to flow less smoothly over the upper surface of the [[airfoil]] and begins to separate from the upper surface. On most airfoil shapes, as the angle of attack increases, the upper surface separation point of the flow moves from the trailing edge towards the leading edge. At the critical angle of attack, upper surface flow is more separated and the airfoil or wing is producing its maximum lift coefficient. As angle of attack increases further, the upper surface flow becomes more fully separated and the lift coefficient reduces further.<ref name="nasa-lc" />
Above this critical angle of attack, the aircraft is said to be in a [[Stall (fluid dynamics)|stall]]. A fixed-wing aircraft by definition is stalled at or above the critical angle of attack rather than at or below a particular [[airspeed]]. The airspeed at which the aircraft stalls varies with the weight of the aircraft, the [[load factor (aeronautics)|load factor]], the center of gravity of the aircraft and other factors. However the aircraft always stalls at the same critical angle of attack. The critical or stalling angle of attack is typically around 15° - 20° for many airfoils.
Some aircraft are equipped with a built-in flight computer that automatically prevents the aircraft from increasing the angle of attack any further when a maximum angle of attack is reached, regardless of pilot input. This is called the 'angle of attack limiter' or 'alpha limiter'. Modern airliners that have fly-by-wire technology avoid the critical angle of attack by means of software in the computer systems that govern the flight control surfaces.
In takeoff and landing operations from short runways, such as Naval Aircraft Carrier operations and [[STOL]] back country flying, aircraft may be equipped with angle of attack or [[Airspeed indicator#Variations|Lift Reserve Indicators]]. These indicators measure the angle of attack (AOA) or the Potential of Wing Lift (POWL, or Lift Reserve) directly and help the pilot fly close to the stalling point with greater precision. [[STOL]] operations require the aircraft to be able to operate close to the critical angle of attack during landings and at the best angle of climb during takeoffs. Angle of attack indicators are used by pilots for maximum performance during these maneuvers since airspeed information is only indirectly related to stall behaviour.
==Very high alpha== [[File:Su-35 (12509727094).jpg|thumb|Su-27M / [[Su-35]] at high angle of attack]]
{{further information|High Alpha Research Vehicle}}
Some military aircraft are able to achieve controlled flight at very high angles of attack, but at the cost of massive [[induced drag]]. This provides the aircraft with great agility. A famous military example is sometimes thought to be [[Pugachev's Cobra]]. Although the aircraft experiences high angles of attack throughout the maneuver, the aircraft is not capable of either aerodynamic directional control or maintaining level flight until the maneuver ends. The Cobra is an example of [[Supermaneuverability|supermaneuvering]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Ti3lNwAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Timothy+John+Cowan%22&source=bl&ots=3a8KzWbZih&sig=yPdiiPriU8W7QSv3DCDb0guA3HI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0PCCUIW4MaS-2gWPlIHICw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA Timothy Cowan]</ref><ref>[http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a224126.pdf DTIC]</ref> as the aircraft's wings are well beyond the critical angle of attack for most of the maneuver.
Additional aerodynamic surfaces known as "high-lift devices" including [[Leading edge extension#Leading edge root extensions|leading edge wing root extensions]] allow [[fighter aircraft]] much greater flyable 'true' alpha, up to over 45°, compared to about 20° for aircraft without these devices. This can be helpful at high altitudes where even slight maneuvering may require high angles of attack due to the low density of air in the upper atmosphere as well as at low speed at low altitude where the margin between level flight AoA and stall AoA is reduced. The high AoA capability of the aircraft provides a buffer for the pilot that makes stalling the airplane (which occurs when critical AoA is exceeded) more difficult. However, military aircraft usually do not obtain such high alpha in combat, as it robs the aircraft of speed very quickly due to induced drag, and in extreme cases, increased frontal area and parasitic drag. Not only do such maneuvers slow the aircraft down, but they cause significant structural stress at high speed. Modern flight control systems tend to limit a fighter's angle of attack to well below its maximum aerodynamic limit.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}}
==Sailing== In [[sailing]], the physical principles involved are the same as for aircraft.<ref name="MIT - How Sails Work">{{cite web|last=Evans|first=Robin C.|title=HOW A SAIL BOAT SAILS INTO THE WIND|url=http://web.mit.edu/2.972/www/reports/sail_boat/sail_boat.html|work=Reports on How Things Work|publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|accessdate=14 January 2012}}</ref> A sail's '''angle of attack''' is the angle between the sail's chord line and the direction of the relative wind.
A boat's '''angle of attack''' is the angle between the boat's course and the wind direction. See [[points of sail]].
==See also== *[[Advance ratio]] *[[Aircraft principal axes]] *[[Angle of sideslip]] *[[Bernoulli's principle]] *[[Drag equation]] *[[Küssner effect]] *[[Lift (force)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
* Lawford, J.A. and Nippress, K.R.; [http://spaceagecontrol.com/AD-CalibrationOfAirDataSystemsAndFlowDirectionSensors.pdf Calibration of Air-data Systems and Flow Direction Sensors] (NATO) Advisory Group for Aerospace Research and Development, AGARDograph No. 300 Vol. 1 (AGARD AG-300 Vol. 1); "Calibration of Air-data Systems and Flow Direction Sensors"; Aeroplane and Armament Experimental Establishment, Boscombe Down, Salisbury, Wilts SP4 OJF, United Kingdom * USAF & NATO Report RTO-TR-015 AC/323/(HFM-015)/TP-1 (2001).
{{DEFAULTSORT:Angle Of Attack}} [[Category:Aerodynamics]] [[Category:Aircraft wing design]] [[Category:Kites]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2006}} The '''Australian Atomic Energy Commission''' ('''AAEC''') was a [[statutory body]] of the [[Australia]]n government.
It was established in 1952, replacing the Atomic Energy Policy Committee. In 1981 parts of the Commission were split off to become part of [[CSIRO]], the remainder continuing until 1987, when it was replaced by the [[Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation]] (ANSTO). The Commission head office was in [[Coogee, New South Wales|Coogee]], and its main facilities were at the Atomic Energy Research Establishment at [[Lucas Heights]], established in 1958.
Highlights of the Commission's history included:
*Major roles in the establishment of the [[IAEA]] and the system of international safeguards. *The construction of the [[HIFAR]] and [[MOATA]] research reactors at Lucas Heights. *The selection of the preferred tender for the construction of the proposed [[Jervis Bay Nuclear Power Plant]]. *The [[Ranger Uranium Mine]] joint venture.
Other significant facilities constructed by the Commission at Lucas Heights included a 3[[Electronvolt|MeV]] [[Van de Graaff generator|Van de Graaff]] [[particle accelerator]], installed in 1964 to provide [[proton]] beams and now upgraded to become [[ANTARES (accelerator)|ANTARES]], a smaller 1.3MeV [[betatron]], and [[radioisotope]] production and remote handling facilities associated with HIFAR reactor.
Significant research work included:
*[[Radiochemistry]]. *[[Neutron diffraction]]. *[[Sodium]] coolant systems. *Use of [[beryllium]] as a [[neutron moderator]]. *Movement of spheres in a closed-packed lattice. *[[Gas centrifuge]] development. *[[Health physics]]. *[[Environmental science]]. *Development of [[synroc]]. *[[Molecular laser isotope separation]]<ref>[[A. W. Pryor]], Personal memories of two advanced uranium enrichment projects at Lucas Heights in the years 1972-1980, ''The Australian & New Zealand Physicist'' '''33''' (3-4), 53-58 (1997).</ref> and support of laser development for [[atomic vapor laser isotope separation]].<ref>[[F. J. Duarte]], [http://www.tunablelasers.com/F.%20J.%20Duarte%20Australian%20Physics%2047%2038-40%20%282010%29.pdf Tunable lasers for atomic vapor laser isotope separation: the Australian contribution, ''Australian Physics'' '''47'''(2), 38-40 (2010)].</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Commonwealth Government agencies of Australia]] [[Category:Nuclear organizations]] [[Category:Scientific organisations based in Australia]] [[Category:Nuclear energy in Australia]] [[Category:Nuclear technology in Australia]] [[Category:1952 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Lucas Heights, New South Wales]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1952]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2010}} '''Avery Weigh-Tronix''' is a company specialising in [[weighing machine]]s. Its headquarters stands on the site of the [[Soho Foundry]] overlooking [[Black Patch Park]] in [[Smethwick]], [[England]], with a [[United States]]-based [[manufacturing]] and [[retail]] manufacturing plant.
Avery Weigh-Tronix (AWTX UK) is the UK’s largest manufacturer of scales and weighing equipment. AWTX is a company specialising in the service, maintenance, calibration and sales of weighing equipment. AWTX also offer nationwide cover for scale and IT-based product installation, repair and maintenance through a network of service centres and technicians.
It was formed in June 2000 when United States weighing company Weigh-Tronix acquired the [[Avery Berkel]] group of businesses, bringing together the four [[brand]]s of [[W & T Avery Ltd.|W & T Avery]], Berkel, [[Salter Housewares|Salter]] and [[Weigh-Tronix]]. Avery Weigh-Tronix is one of the world’s largest manufacturers of weighing equipment.
On the Soho Foundry site the company runs one of the very few Museums of Weighing in the world; admission by appointment only.
==Corporate family== The Illinois Tool Works or [[ITW]] (NYSE: ITW) is a [[Fortune 200]] company that produces engineered fasteners and components, equipment and consumable systems, and specialty products. It was founded in 1912 by Byron L. Smith.
The consolidation of the group was finally completed in September 2003, when the change of name to Avery Weigh-Tronix created a single corporate entity to service today’s global markets.
==Salter Brecknell== Avery Weigh-Tronix also sells products under the brand name Salter Brecknell: scales are sold through a dealer-distributor network and direct to some retailers, including mechanical and consumer products.
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.averyweigh-tronix.com/ Avery Weigh-Tronix Corporate website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070218121449/http://www.averyweigh-tronix.com/museum/ Museum] *[http://www.salterbrecknell.com/ Salter Brecknell]
[[Category:Companies based in Smethwick]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Weighing scale manufacturers]]
