revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Kids Saving the Rainforest (KTSR) | image = Kids_Saving_the_Rainforest_Logo.jpg | image_size = | alt = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = KSTR | motto = Protect the diverse wildlife of Costa Rica’s Pacific Coast by rehabilitating wildlife, conducting original scientific research, training volunteers, and promoting conservation. | formation = {{start date and age|df=yes|1999|02}} | founders = {{plainlist| * Janine Licare * Aislin Livingstone * Jennifer Rice }} | type = [[NGO]] | tax_id = | registration_id = | status = | purpose = {{plainlist| * [[Environmentalism]] * [[Conservation (ethic)|Conservation]] * [[Ecology]] }} | headquarters = Manuel Antonio, Costa Rica
Palo Alto, California | location = | coords = | region = [[Costa Rica]], [[Peru]], [[California]] | methods = {{hlist|animal rescue |animal rehabilitation |reforestation}} | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | leader_title = President | leader_name = Jennifer Rice, PHD | leader_title2 = Chairman of the Board, Regent | leader_name2 = Pia Martin, DVM | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = [http://www.kidssavingtherainforest.org/ kidssavingtherainforest.org] | remarks = | footnotes = }} '''Kids Saving the Rainforest (KSTR)''' is a Costa Rica-based non-governmental non-profit 501 C3 organization founded in 1999 to plant trees in depleted areas of the country, and to rescue, rehabilitate and, when possible, release the animals who live in these forests. Since its inception, Kids Saving the Rainforest has planted or is in the process of planting nearly 100,000 trees and rescued and rehabilitated 3,000 wild animals, two-thirds of which have been released back into the wild. KSTR's mission is: "to protect the diverse wildlife of Costa Rica’s Pacific Coast by rehabilitating wildlife, conducting original scientific research, training volunteers, and promoting conservation." ==History== Kids Saving the Rainforest was founded in February 1999 by two nine-year old girls, Janine Licare and Aislin Livingstone, who were living in the jungle of Manuel Antonio, Costa Rica.{{cite news|last1=Christ|first1=Costas|title=Generation Next: The World’s Young Eco Warriors|url=http://intelligenttravel.nationalgeographic.com/2015/06/25/generation-next-the-worlds-young-eco-warriors/?_ga=2.145704752.508656980.1516898071-77794039.1516898071|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=National Geographic|date=June 25, 2015}} The girls made paper-mache bottles and painted rocks and sold them by the side of the road to raise money for saplings that would be planted in the nearby forest.{{cite news|last1=Ries|first1=Olivia|title=KIDS SAVING THE RAINFOREST|url=https://blog.education.nationalgeographic.org/2016/04/13/kids-saving-the-rainforest/|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=National Geographic 2|date=April 13, 2016}} Since then, KSTR has become a fully functional environmental organization with a board of directors.{{cite web|title=Volunteer in Costa Rica with Kids Saving the Rainforest|url=https://www.healthcarevolunteer.com/volunteers/viewpagelogin.php?orgname=Volunteer%20in%20Costa%20Rica%20with%20Kids%20Saving%20the%20Rainforest|website=healthcarevolunteer.com|accessdate=25 January 2018}} Licare's mother, Jennifer Rice is president. The staff includes a number of full-time people plus volunteers.{{cite news|last1=Dale|first1=Paula|title=Get entranced by rugged rain forests, vast volcanoes and wildlife watching in Costa Rica|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/lifestyle/travel/usa-long-haul/entranced-rugged-rain-forests-vast-9745522|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=Mirror|date=February 4, 2017}} KSTR is located outside Manual Antonio, Costa Rica, but has projects in 18 countries. ==Programs== ===Rescue, rehabilitate and release=== KSTR rescues and rehabs animals that are brought to their facility. In addition, the ones that can not be released back into the wild are given sanctuary for life on the property.{{cite news|last1=Arnold|first1=Carrie|title=Unbelievably Cute Pictures of Rescued Baby Sloths|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2016/07/sloths-conservation-animals-endangered-costa-rica/?_ga=2.145236016.508656980.1516898071-77794039.1516898071|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=National Geographic 3|date=July 20, 2016}} The goal is to release as many animals as possible. With an average of 200 rescues a year, over 75 species have been rescued at their center. This includes, among others, two- and three-toed sloths, squirrel monkeys, kinkajous, coatis, marmosets, tamarins, orange-chinned parakeets.{{cite news|last1=Weissmann|first1=Emma|title=See Sloths, Monkeys and More at This Costa Rica Sanctuary|url=http://www.travelagewest.com/Travel/Central-South-America/See-Sloths--Monkeys-and-More-at-This-Costa-Rica-Sanctuary/#.Wm5nwIjwbIV|accessdate=29 January 2018|work=Travel Age West|date=April 23, 2017}} ===Wildlife bridges=== KSTR started a Wildlife Bridge Program in 2000, originally to protect the endangered titi monkeys (squirrel monkey). They have since put up 130 bridges and 14 different animal species have been using them.{{cite news|last1=Ries|first1=Olivia|title=MONKEY BRIDGES FOR EVERYONE|url=https://blog.education.nationalgeographic.org/2016/05/18/monkey-bridges-for-everyone/|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=National Geographic 4|date=May 18, 2016}} Meanwhile, the titi monkey population has doubled.{{cite web|title=Blog:Kids Saving the Rainforest|url=https://www.imaginetravel.com/imagine-latin-america/holiday-destination/costa-rica/our-costa-rica/kids-saving-the-rainforest|website=imaginetravel.com|accessdate=29 January 2018}} Whenever an arboreal animal is electrocuted by live wires, hit by a car, or attacked by dogs, KSTR reviews the necessity of a bridge and places it for them to cross high off the ground. ===Reforestation=== Since its inception, KSTR has planted over 7,000 trees,{{cite news|last1=Wallace|first1=Sue|title=STAR PRIDE, WINDSTAR CRUISES, QUEPOS: HIGHLIGHTS AND WILDLIFE RESCUE CENTRE, COSTA RICA|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/life/travel/shore-excursions-abandon-ship-for-some-lasting-impressions/news-story/416ae4d65bcc02ed65f3234fcfb3c440|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=The Australian|date=November 18, 2017}} is in the process of planting another 80,000 on donated property elsewhere in Costa Rica,{{cite news|last1=MacKinnon|first1=Jannette|title=How Kids Helped Save the Rainforest|url=https://thecostaricanews.com/how-kids-can-help-save-the-rainforest/|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=Costa Rica news|date=October 2, 2016}} and reforests in other countries as well. ===Volunteers=== In order to run its facility and care for the animals, KSTR relies on volunteers who come in from around the world to help with all aspects of its programs. The volunteers clean, repair, and build cages, work on trails, prepare food for the animals, observe behavior, and more.{{cite web|title=Kids Saving the Rainforest|url=https://www.idealist.org/en/nonprofit/67510b4079c14f319aaf350b5f0cecb6-kids-saving-the-rainforest-manuel-antonio?|website=idealist.org|accessdate=29 January 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Manley|first1=Harriot|title=Where to Go in 2018 -- And Make a Difference|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/travel/article/Where-to-Go-in-2018-and-make-a-differelnce-12460199.php|accessdate=29 January 2018|work=SF Chronicle|date=December 28, 2017}} Many volunteers are housed where they work at KSTR, but some opt for a day of volunteer work offered by area tour companies.{{cite web|last1=Merry|first1=Mitch|title=World’s Cutest In-Patients|url=http://www.endangered.org/worlds-cutest-in-patients/|website=endangered.org|accessdate=29 January 2018}} ===Education=== A key element of KSTR is education about biodiversity conservation.{{cite web|title=Kids Saving the Rainforest|url=https://www.latafoundation.org/projects/kids-saving-the-rainforest/|website=latafoundation.org|accessdate=29 January 2018}} Visitors who take the tours of the facility are given an educational talk about the rainforest and its inhabitants. ==Funding== KSTR operates entirely on donations.{{cite web|title=KIDS SAVING THE RAINFOREST IN COSTA RICA|url=http://www.cazloyd.com/en-gb/2015/06/08/kids-saving-the-rainforest/|website=cazloyd.com|accessdate=29 January 2018}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{environmental-org-stub}} [[Category:Animal rescue groups]] [[Category:Environmental organizations based in Costa Rica]]

A '''[[lightning]] strike''' or '''lightning bolt''' is an [[electric discharge]] between the [[atmosphere]] and an Earth-bound object.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} They mostly originate in a [[cumulonimbus cloud]] and terminate on the ground, called cloud to ground (CG) lightning. A less common type of strike, called ground to cloud (GC), is upward propagating lightning initiated from a tall grounded object and reaches into the clouds. About 25% of all lightning events worldwide are strikes between the atmosphere and earth-bound objects. The bulk of lightning events are intra-cloud (IC) or cloud to cloud (CC), where discharges only occur high in the atmosphere.<ref>Cooray, Vernon. (2014). Lightning Flash (2nd Edition) - 1. Charge Structure and Geographical Variation of Thunderclouds. Page 4. Institution of Engineering and Technology.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thunder.nsstc.nasa.gov/primer/primer2.html |title=GHRC: Lightning Characteristics |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305002214/http://thunder.nsstc.nasa.gov/primer/primer2.html |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }}</ref>
A single lightning event is a "flash", which is a complex, multi-stage process, some parts of which are not fully understood. Most cloud to ground flashes only "strike" one physical location, referred to as a "termination". The primary conducting channel, the bright coursing light that may be seen and is called a "strike", is only about 30 feet in diameter, but because of its extreme brilliance, it often looks much larger to the human eye and in photographs. Lightning discharges are typically miles long, but certain types of horizontal discharges can be upwards of tens of miles in length. The entire flash lasts only a fraction of a second. Most of the early formative and propagation stages are much dimmer and not visible to the human eye.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
[[File:-D3- LighningStormPanorama.jpg|thumb|600px|Panorama photography taken during a lightning storm over [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]]]]
== Strikes ==
Lightning strikes can injure humans in several different ways:<ref name=Ritenour>{{cite journal |author=Ritenour AE, Morton MJ, McManus JG, Barillo DJ, Cancio LC |title=Lightning injury: a review |journal=Burns |volume=34 |issue=5 |pages=585–94 |date=2008 |pmid=18395987 |doi=10.1016/j.burns.2007.11.006|last2=Morton |last3=McManus |last4=Barillo |last5=Cancio |url=http://www.dtic.mil/get-tr-doc/pdf?AD=ADA627751 }}</ref> # '''Direct''' #* Direct strike – the person is part of a flash channel. Enormous quantities of energy pass through the body very quickly, resulting in internal burns, organ damage, explosions of flesh and bone, and nervous system damage. Depending on the flash strength and access to medical services, it may be instantaneously fatal or cause permanent injury and impairment. #* Contact injury – an object, generally a conductor, is electrified by a strike that a person was touching. #* Side splash – branches of currents "jumping" from the primary flash channel, electrify the person. #* Blast injuries – being thrown and suffering [[blunt trauma|blunt force trauma]] from the shock wave (if very close) and possible [[Hearing damage#Physical trauma|hearing damage]] from the thunder.<ref>{{Citation | url= http://lightningsafety.com/nlsi_info/thunder2.html | title = The Science of Thunder | date = 13 March 2018 | publisher = [[NLSI]] | publication-place = [[United States]] }}</ref> # '''Indirect''' #* Ground current or "step potential" – Earth surface charges race towards the flash channel during discharge. Because the ground has high impedance, the current "chooses" a better conductor, often a person's legs, passing through the body. The near-instantaneous rate of discharge causes a potential (difference) over distance, which may amount to several thousand volts per linear foot. This phenomenon is responsible for more injuries and deaths than the above three combined, with reports such as "hundreds of reindeer killed by a lightning storm..." being a classic example.<ref>{{Citation | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-37214288 | title = Reindeer killed in Norway lightning storm | date = 29 August 2016 | publisher = [[BBC News]] | publication-place = [[United Kingdom]] }}</ref> #* EMPs – the discharge process produces an electromagnetic pulse ([[Electromagnetic pulse|EMP]]) which may damage an artificial pacemaker, or otherwise affect normal biological processes. # '''Secondary or resultant''' #* Explosions #* Fires #* Accidents
== Injuries == {{Main|Lightning injuries}} Lightning strikes can produce severe injuries, and have a [[mortality rate]] of between 10% and 30%, with up to 80% of survivors sustaining long-term injuries. These severe injuries are not usually caused by thermal burns, since the current is too brief to greatly heat up tissues; instead, nerves and muscles may be directly damaged by the high voltage producing holes in their [[cell membrane]]s, a process called [[electroporation]].<ref name=Ritenour />
In a direct strike, the [[electrical current]]s in the flash channel pass directly through the victim. The relatively high voltage drop around poorer electrical conductors (such as a human being), causes the surrounding air to ionize and break down, and the external flashover diverts most of the main discharge current so that it passes "around" the body, reducing injury.
Metallic objects in contact with the skin may "concentrate" the lightning's energy, given it is a better natural conductor and the preferred pathway, resulting in more serious injuries, such as burns from molten or evaporating metal. At least two cases have been reported where a strike victim wearing an [[iPod]] suffered more serious injuries as a result.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Va-stag B |title=fry Pod: Lightning strikes iPod users |journal=Science News |volume=172 |issue=3 |date=2007}}</ref>
However, during a flash, the current flowing through the channel and around the body will generate large [[Electromagnetic pulse|electromagnetic fields and EMPs]], which may [[Electromagnetic induction|induce]] [[Voltage spike|electrical transients (surges)]] within the [[Action potential|nervous system]] or [[Cardiac pacemaker|pacemaker]] of the heart, upsetting [[Homeostasis|normal operations]]. This effect might explain cases where [[cardiac arrest]] or [[Non-epileptic seizure|seizures]] followed a lightning strike that produced no external injuries. It may also point to the victim not being directly struck at all, but just being very close to the strike termination.<ref name=Ritenour/>
Another effect of lightning on bystanders is to their [[Hearing (sense)|hearing]]. The resulting [[shock wave]] of [[thunder]] can damage the ears. Also, [[Electromagnetic interference|electrical interference]] to telephones or headphones may result in damaging [[acoustic noise]].
==Epidemiology==
[[File:US Lightning Deaths.png|thumb|A dot density map portraying male and female deaths by lightning strike between 2007 and 2017.]]
[[File:20150506-LondonGardenMuseum-8.jpg|thumb|Memorial to a lightning victim in 1787 in London in a window]] One estimate is that 24,000 people are killed by lightning strikes around the world each year and about 240,000 are injured. <ref>Ronald L. Holle [http://www.vaisala.com/Vaisala%20Documents/Scientific%20papers/Annual_rates_of_lightning_fatalities_by_country.pdf Annual rates of lightning fatalities by country]. (PDF) . 0th International Lightning Detection Conference. 21–23 April 2008. Tucson, Arizona, USA. Retrieved on 2011-11-08.</ref>
Another estimate is that the annual global death toll is 6,000. <ref>{{cite web |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140727091112/http://www.icae2011.net.br/upload/287_20110606115236I.Cardoso-ANEWAPPROACHTOESTIMATETHEANNUALNUMBEROFGLOBALLIGHTNINGFATALITIES.doc |archivedate= 27 July 2014 |title=A NEW APPROACH TO ESTIMATE THE ANNUAL NUMBER OF GLOBAL LIGHTNING FATALITIES|url=http://www.icae2011.net.br/upload/287_20110606115236I.Cardoso-ANEWAPPROACHTOESTIMATETHEANNUALNUMBEROFGLOBALLIGHTNINGFATALITIES.doc|accessdate=20 July 2014}}</ref>
According to the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]], over the last 20 years, the [[United States]] averaged 51 annual lightning strike fatalities, placing it in the second position, just behind [[flood]]s for deadly weather.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jedick|first=Rocky|title=Flight Surgeon Busts Lightning Myths|url=http://www.afms.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123316472|publisher=AFMS|accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="lightningsafe">[https://web.archive.org/web/20051029004621/http://www.lightningsafety.noaa.gov/resources/Ltg%20Safety-Facts.pdf Lightning Safety Facts]. lightningsafety.noaa.gov (archived)</ref> In the US, between 9% and 10% of those struck die,<ref>Cherington, J. et al. 1999: Closing the Gap on the Actual Numbers of Lightning Casualties and Deaths. Preprints, 11th Conf. on Applied Climatology, 379-80.[http://www.uic.edu/labs/lightninginjury/Disability.pdf].</ref> for an average of 40 to 50 deaths per year (28 in 2008).<ref> {{cite web | title = 2008 Lightning Fatalities | work = light08.pdf | publisher = NOAA | date = 2009-04-22 | url = http://www.nws.noaa.gov/om/hazstats/light08.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 7 October 2009}}</ref>
In [[Kisii, Kenya|Kisii]] in western [[Kenya]], some 30 people die each year from lightning strikes. Kisii's high rate of lightning fatalities occurs because of the frequency of thunderstorms and because many of the area's structures have metal roofs.<ref>National Geographic Almanac of Geography (2005), {{ISBN|0-7922-3877-X}}, page 78.</ref>
These statistics do not reflect the difference between direct strikes, where the victim was part of the lightning pathway, indirect effects of being close to the termination point, like ground currents, and resultant, where the casualty arose from subsequent events, such as fires or explosions. Even the most knowledgeable [[first responder]]s may not recognize a lightning related injury, let alone particulars, which a [[medical examiner]], [[Police detective|police investigator]] or on the rare occasion a trained lightning expert may have difficulty identifying to record accurately. This ignores the reality that lightning, as the first event, may [[Causation (law)|assume responsibility]] for the overall and resulting accident.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
Direct strike casualties could be much higher than reported numbers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Monheim, MS Sgt. (Ret.)|first=Tony|title=THE SHOCKING TRUTH ABOUT LIGHTNING DEATHS|url=http://patc.com/weeklyarticles/lightning.shtml|publisher=Public Agency Training Council|accessdate=17 March 2013}}</ref>
==Effect on nature==
===Impact on vegetation=== [[File:Lightning damage.jpg|thumb|A green tree which was struck by lightning, exploding the trunk.]] [[File:Lightning struck tree 2.jpg|thumb|A [[eucalyptus tree]] that was struck by lightning, while two nearby [[pine tree]]s were untouched, [[Darwin, Northern Territory]], Australia.]]
Trees are frequent [[Conductor (material)|conductors]] of lightning to the ground.<ref name="tree1">{{cite web|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/lwx/lightning/lgtng-hits-tree.jpg|title=Image of lightning hitting a tree|accessdate=September 24, 2007|publisher=National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration|author=National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration|format=.jpg| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061020011352/http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/lwx/lightning/lgtng-hits-tree.jpg| archivedate = October 20, 2006}}</ref> Since [[sap (plant)|sap]] is a relatively poor conductor, its [[electrical resistance]] causes it to be heated [[steam explosion|explosively]] into steam, which blows off the [[Bark (botany)|bark]] outside the lightning's path. In following seasons trees overgrow the damaged area and may cover it completely, leaving only a vertical scar. If the damage is severe, the tree may not be able to recover, and [[Bacterial decay|decay]] sets in, eventually killing the tree.
In sparsely populated areas such as the [[Russian Far East]] and [[Siberia]], lightning strikes are one of the major causes of [[forest fire]]s.<ref name=journal>{{cite journal|date=September 1996 |title=Lightning as a source of forest fires |journal=Combustion, Explosion, and Shock Waves |publisher=Springer New York |volume=32 |issue=5 |pages=134–142 |issn=0010-5082 |url=http://resources.metapress.com/pdf-preview.axd?code=m6427q0uj860w333&size=largest |accessdate=2009-07-25 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826024450/http://resources.metapress.com/pdf-preview.axd?code=m6427q0uj860w333&size=largest |archivedate=2011-08-26 |df= }}</ref> The smoke and mist expelled by a very large forest fire can cause electric charges, starting additional fires many kilometers downwind.<ref name="journal"/>
===Shattering of rocks=== When water in [[Fracture (geology)|fractured rock]] is rapidly heated by a lightning strike, the resulting steam explosion can cause rock disintegration and shift boulders. It may be a significant factor in erosion of tropical and subtropical mountains that have never been glaciated. Evidence of lightning strikes includes erratic magnetic fields.<ref>[http://www.wits.ac.za/newsroom/newsitems/201310/21737/news_item_21737.html Foss, Kanina, ''New evidence on lightning strikes'' University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, Press release, 15 October 2013] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005162551/http://www.wits.ac.za/newsroom/newsitems/201310/21737/news_item_21737.html |date= 5 October 2015 }}</ref><ref>Knight, Jasper and Stefan W. Grab, ''Lightning as a geomorphic agent on mountain summits: Evidence from southern Africa,'' ''Geomorphology,'' Volume 204, 1 January 2014, Pages 61–70 [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169555X13003929 abstract]</ref>
== Electrical and structural damage == [[File:Zephyrometer Lightning Damage.JPG|thumb|A sculpture damaged by lightning in Wellington, New Zealand]] [[File:Lightning striking the Eiffel Tower - NOAA.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Eiffel Tower]] as a colossal lightning conductor. Photograph taken 1902-06-03 21:02]]
[[Telephone]]s, [[modem]]s, [[computer]]s and other electronic devices can be damaged by lightning, as harmful [[overcurrent]] can reach them through the [[Jack (connector)|phone jack]], [[Ethernet cable]], or [[AC power plugs and sockets|electricity outlet]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Summer tips for telecom users |journal=Blog.anta.net |date=2008-06-17 |url=http://blog.anta.net/2008/06/17/summer-tips-for-telecom-users/ |issn=1797-1993 |accessdate=2008-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081118201527/http://blog.anta.net/2008/06/17/summer-tips-for-telecom-users/ |archivedate=2008-11-18 |df= }}</ref> Close strikes can also generate electromagnetic pulses ([[Electromagnetic pulse|EMP]]s) – especially during [[Lightning#Positive and negative lightning|"positive"]] lightning discharges.
Lightning currents have a very fast [[rise time]], on the order of 40 kA per microsecond. Hence, conductors of such currents exhibit marked [[skin effect]], causing most of the currents to flow through the outer surface of the conductor.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Nair, Z., Aparna K.M., Khandagale R.S., Gopalan T.V. | title =Failure of 220 kV double circuit transmission line tower due to lightning | journal =Journal of Performance of Constructed Facilities | volume =19 | issue =2 | pages =132 | date=2005| doi = 10.1061/(ASCE)0887-3828(2005)19:2(132)}}</ref>
In addition to electrical wiring damage, the other types of possible damage to consider include structural, fire, and property damage.
==Prevention and mitigations== The field of lightning protection systems is an enormous industry worldwide due to the impacts lightning can have on the constructs and activities of humankind. Lightning, as varied in properties measured across [[Order of magnitude|orders of magnitude]] as it is, can cause direct effects or have secondary impacts; lead to the complete destruction of a facility or process or simply cause the failure of a remote electronic sensor; it can result in outdoor activities being halted for safety concerns to employees as a thunderstorm nears an area and until it has sufficiently passed; it can ignite volatile commodities stored in large quantities or interfere with the normal operation of a piece of equipment at critical periods of time.
Most lightning protection devices and systems protect physical structures on the earth, aircraft in flight being the notable exception. While some attention has been paid to attempting to control lightning in the atmosphere, all attempts proved extremely limited in success. Chaff and silver iodide crystal concepts were devised to deal directly with the cloud cells and were dispensed directly into the clouds from an overflying aircraft. The chaff was devised to deal with the electrical manifestations of the storm from within, while the silver iodide salting technique was devised to deal with the mechanical forces of the storm.
=== Lightning protection systems === [[File:Pointed Lightning Rod.jpg|thumb|right|180px|An example of a standard, pointed-tip, air terminal.]] {{Main|Lightning rod}} {{see also|Lightning arrestor|Surge protector}}
Hundreds of devices, including [[lightning rod]]s and charge transfer systems, are used to mitigate lightning damage and influence the path of a lightning flash.
A lightning rod (or lightning protector) is a metal strip or rod connected to earth through [[conductor (material)|conductors]] and a grounding system, used to provide a preferred pathway to ground if lightning terminates on a structure. The class of these products are often called a "finial" or "air terminal". A lightning rod or "Franklin rod" in honor of its famous inventor, [[Benjamin Franklin]], is simply a metal rod, and without being connected to the lightning protection system, as was sometimes the case in the old days, will provide no added protection to a structure. Other names include "lightning conductor", "arrester", and "discharger"; however, over the years these names have been incorporated into other products or industries with a stake in lightning protection. Lightning arrester, for example, often refers to fused links that explode when a strike occurs to a high voltage overhead power line to protect the more expensive transformers down the line by opening the circuit. In reality, it was an early form of a heavy duty [[Surge Protector|surge protection device (SPD)]]. Modern arresters, constructed with metal oxides, are capable of safely shunting abnormally high voltage surges to ground while preventing normal system voltages from being shorted to ground.
=== Monitoring and warning systems === [[File:IStrike Lightning Siren in Noblesville, IN.jpg|thumb|iStrike Lightning Siren System w/ Strobe currently in use in Noblesville, IN]] [[File:Lightning warning system 1.jpg|thumb|160px|A Thor Guard [[lightning prediction system]]]]
The exact location of a lightning strike or when it will occur is still impossible to predict. However, products and systems have been designed of varying complexities to alert people as the probability of a strike increases above a set level determined by a [[risk assessment]] for the location's conditions and circumstances. One significant improvement has been in the area of detection of flashes through both ground and satellite-based observation devices. The strikes and atmospheric flashes are not predicted, however the level of detail recorded by these technologies has vastly improved in the past 20 years.
Although commonly associated with thunderstorms at close range, lightning strikes can occur on a day that seems devoid of clouds. This occurrence is known as "A Bolt From the Blue";<ref>[http://www.crh.noaa.gov/pub/ltg/crh_boltblue.php NWS Pueblo Lightning Page – Bolts From The Blue]. Crh.noaa.gov. Retrieved on 2011-11-08.</ref> lightning can strike up to 10 miles from a cloud.
Lightning interferes with AM ([[amplitude modulation]]) radio signals much more than FM ([[frequency modulation]]) signals, providing an easy way to gauge local lightning strike intensity.<ref>Joni Jantunen ''et al.'' "Detection of lightning" {{US patent|7254484}} Issue date: August 7, 2007</ref> To do so, one should tune a standard AM [[medium wave]] receiver to a frequency with no transmitting stations, and listen for crackles amongst the [[Noise (radio)|static]]. Stronger or nearby lightning strikes will also cause cracking if the receiver is tuned to a station. As lower frequencies propagate further along the ground than higher ones, the lower medium wave (MW) band frequencies (in the 500–600 kHz range) can detect lightning strikes at longer distances; if the longwave band (153–279 kHz) is available, using it can increase this range even further.
[[Lightning detector|Lightning detection systems]] have been developed and may be deployed in locations where lightning strikes present special risks, such as public parks. Such systems are designed to detect the conditions which are believed to favor lightning strikes and provide a warning to those in the vicinity to allow them to take appropriate cover.
=== Personal safety === The U.S. National Lightning Safety Institute<ref>[http://www.lightningsafety.com/nlsi_pls/lst.html Personal Lightning Safety Tips] National Lightning Safety Institute . Accessed July 2008</ref> advises American citizens to have a plan for their safety when a thunderstorm occurs and to commence it as soon as the first lightning is seen or thunder heard. This is important as lightning can strike without rain actually falling. If thunder can be heard at all, then there is a risk of lightning. The safest place is inside a building or a vehicle. Risk remains for up to 30 minutes after the last observed lightning or thunder.
The National Lightning Safety Institute recommends using the F-B (flash to boom) method to gauge distance to a lightning strike. The flash of a lightning strike and resulting thunder occur at roughly the same time. But light travels 300,000 kilometers in a second, almost a million times the speed of sound. Sound travels at the slower speed of 344 m/s, so the flash of lightning is seen before thunder is heard. A method to determine the distance between lightning strike and viewer, involves counting the seconds between the lightning flash and thunder. Then, dividing by three to determine the distance in kilometers, or by five for miles. Immediate precautions against lightning should be taken if the F-B time is 25 seconds or less, that is, if the lightning is closer than {{convert|8|km|mi|abbr=on}}.
Reports differ regarding what to do if caught outside during a storm. One study shows that [[prostration]] is safer than lying down flat when there are no other alternatives.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Adel|first=Miah M|title=Superiority of Prostration as a Protection from Lightning Strike|journal=Physics International|date=2012|volume=3|issue=1|pages=9–21|doi=10.3844/pisp.2012.9.21|url=http://thescipub.com/abstract/10.3844/pisp.2012.9.21|bibcode=2012PhyIn...3....9A}}</ref> A contrasting report suggested that it did not matter whether a person was standing up, [[Squatting position|squatting]], or lying down when outside during a thunderstorm, because lightning can travel along the ground; this report suggested it was safest to be inside a solid structure or vehicle.<ref name=twsNBC>JONEL ALECCIA, June 20, 2014, NBC News, [http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/debunked-5-lightning-myths-could-kill-you-n135971 Debunked: 5 Lightning Myths That Could Kill You], Accessed June 20, 2014</ref> In the [[United States]], the average annual death toll from lightning is 51 deaths per year, although there were only 23 deaths in 2013, which was a record low; the riskiest activities include fishing, boating, camping, and golf.<ref name=twsNBC/> A person injured by lightning does not carry an electrical charge, and can be safely handled to apply [[first aid]] before emergency services arrive. Lightning can affect the brainstem, which controls breathing.<ref>Dayton, L (1993). [https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg14019042.700 "Science: Secrets of a bolt from the blue"], New Scientist, 1904.</ref>
Several studies conducted in South Asia and Africa suggest that the dangers of lightning are not taken sufficiently seriously there. A research team from the [[University of Colombo]] found that even in neighborhoods which had experienced deaths from lightning, no precautions were taken against future storms. An expert forum convened in 2007 to address how to raise awareness of lightning and improve lightning protection standards, and expressed concern that many countries had no official standards for the installation of [[lightning rod]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scidev.net/global/disasters/feature/striking-back-lightning-in-the-developing-world.html|title=Striking back: lightning in the developing world|work=SciDev.Net}}</ref>
== Notable incidents ==
All events associated or suspected of causing damage are called "lightning incidents" due to four important factors. * Forensic evidence of a lightning termination, in the best investigated examples, are minuscule (a pit in metal smaller than a pen point) or inconclusive (dark coloration). * The object struck may explode or subsequent fires destroy all of the little evidence that may have been available immediately after the strike itself. * The flash channel and discharge itself are not the only causes of injury, ignition or damages, i.e., ground currents or explosions of flammables. * Human sensory acuity is not as fine as that of the milliseconds duration of a lightning flash, and our ability to observe this event is subject to the brain's inability to comprehend it. Lightning detection systems are coming online, both satellite and land based, however their accuracy is still measured in the hundreds to thousands of feet, rarely allowing them to pinpoint the exact location of the termination.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
As such it is often inconclusive, albeit highly probably a lightning flash was involved, hence categorizing it as a "lightning incident" covers all bases.
=== Earth-bound ===
* 1660s: In 1660, lightning ignited the gunpowder magazine at [[Osaka Castle]], [[Japan]]; the resultant explosion set the castle on fire. In 1665, lightning again terminated on the main tower of the castle, igniting a fire which subsequently burned it to its foundation. * 1769: A particularly deadly lightning incident occurred in [[Brescia]], [[Italy]]. Lightning struck the Church of St. Nazaire, igniting the 90 tonnes of gunpowder in its vaults; the resulting explosion killed 3,000 people and destroyed a sixth of the city.<ref>Rakov and Uman, p. 2</ref> * 1902: A lightning strike damaged the upper section of the [[Eiffel Tower]], requiring the reconstruction of its top.<ref>[http://www.paris-things-to-do.co.uk/paris-attraction-la-tour-eiffel-tower.html La Tour Eiffel – The Eiffel Tower – Paris Things To Do – www.paris-things-to-do.co.uk]. Paris-things-to-do.co.uk (2007-01-16). Retrieved on 2012-06-23.</ref> * 1970 July 12: The central mast of the [[Orlunda radio transmitter]] in central Sweden collapsed after a lightning strike destroyed its foundation insulator. * 1994 November 2: A lightning incident led to the explosion of fuel tanks in Dronka, [[Egypt]], causing 469 fatalities.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Evans | first = D | title = An appraisal of underground gas storage technologies and incidents, for the development of risk assessment methodology | page = 121 | publisher = Health and Safety Executive | work = British Geological Survey | url = http://www.hse.gov.uk/research/rrpdf/rr605.pdf | accessdate = 2008-08-14|format=PDF}}</ref><!-- <ref>Mogil, H., Michael. ''Hurricanes, Tornadoes, Floods, Heat Waves, Snow Storms, Global Warming and Other Atmospheric Disturbances''. New York: BlueRed Press Ltd.</ref><ref>Environmental Assessment Services for Permanent Aviation Fuel Facility Environmental Impact Assessment Report. Section H4.2: Incidents Involving Aviation Fuel. Available: http://www.epd.gov.hk/eia/register/report/eiareport/eia_1272006/EIA_Report/appendix/Appendix_H4.pdf</ref><ref>Oil and Gas article at http://www.ogj.com/display_article/13681/7/ARCHI/none/none/1/INDUSTRY-BRIEFS/ (subscription required)</ref> --> * 2005 October 31: Sixty-eight dairy cows, all full of milk, died on a farm at Fernbrook on the [[Waterfall Way]] near [[Dorrigo, New South Wales]], after being involved in a lightning incident. Three others were temporarily paralyzed for several hours, later making a full recovery. The cows were sheltering near a tree when it was struck by lightning and the ground potential followed the path of least resistance through the animals' bodies.<ref>Samantha Williams, [https://web.archive.org/web/20080420202425/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C10117%2C17117877-13762%2C00.html?from=rss Lightning kills 106 cows]. news.com.au (2005-11-03)</ref> * 2007 July: A lightning incident killed up to 30 people when it struck Ushari Dara, a remote mountain village in northwestern [[Pakistan]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Lightning kills 30 people in Pakistan's north | publisher = Reuters | date = 2007-07-20| url =https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/07/20/us-pakistan-lightning-idUSISL17716520070720| accessdate = July 27, 2007}}</ref> * 2011 June 8: A lightning strike sent 77 Air Force cadets to the hospital when it struck in the middle of a training camp at Camp Shelby, Mississippi.<ref>{{cite news | title = Lightning strike at Mississippi military base sends 77 to hospital | publisher = CNN | date = 2011-06-08 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2011/US/06/08/mississippi.lightning/index.html | accessdate = August 25, 2013}}</ref> * 2013 February: Nine South African children were hospitalized after a lightning incident occurred on a cricket field at their school, injuring five children on the pitch and four girls who were walking home.<ref>{{Citation | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21440990 | title = South Africa pupils in hospital after lightning strikes | date = 2013 | publisher = [[BBC News]] | publication-place = [[United Kingdom]] }}</ref> * 2016 May–June: [[Rock am Ring]] festival near [[Frankfurt]] was cancelled after at least 80 people were injured due to lightning in the area.<ref>{{cite news | title = Germany rock festival cancelled after lightning strike | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 2016-06-05 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36451614 | accessdate = 2016-06-06 }}</ref> Additionally 11 children in [[France]] and three adults in [[Germany]] were injured and one man killed in southern [[Poland]] around the same dates.<ref>{{cite news | title = Lightning strikes in Europe: One killed and many injured | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 2016-05-28 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36405482 | accessdate = 2016-06-06 }}</ref> * 2016 August 26: A herd of wild [[reindeer]] was struck on the [[Hardangervidda]] in central [[Norway]], killing 323. [[Norwegian Environment Agency]] spokesman Kjartan Knutsen said it had never heard of such a death toll before. He said he didn't know if multiple strikes occurred, but that they all died in "one moment".<ref>[http://globalnews.ca/news/2908544/lightning-strike-kills-over-300-reindeer-in-norway/ "Lightning strike kills more than 300 reindeer in Norway", by Associated Press, via Global News]</ref> * 2017: The first live recording of a lightning strike on a cardiac rhythm strip occurred in a teenage male who had an [[Implantable loop recorder|implanted loop recorder]] as a cardiac monitor for [[Vasovagal|neurocardiogenic]] syncope.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Altalhi|first1=A|last2=Al-Manea|first2=W|last3=Alqweai|first3=N|last4=Alothman|first4=M|title=Cardiac rhythm recorded by implanted loop recorder during lightning strike.|journal=Annals of Saudi medicine|date=Sep 2017|volume=37|issue=5|pages=401–402|doi=10.5144/0256-4947.2017.401|pmid=28988255}}</ref> *2018: A lightning strike killed at least 16 people and injured dozens more at a Seventh-Day Adventist church in [[Rwanda]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-43362508 Rwanda Seventh-Day Adventist churchgoers killed by lightning]</ref>
=== In-flight ===
* 1963 December 8: [[Pan Am Flight 214]] crashed outside Elkton, Maryland, during a severe electrical storm, with a loss of all 81 passengers and crew. The Boeing 707-121, registered as N709PA, was on the final leg of a San Juan–Baltimore–Philadelphia flight. * 1969 November 14: The [[Apollo 12|Apollo 12 mission's]] Saturn V rocket and its ionized exhaust plume became part of a lightning flash channel 36.5 seconds after lift-off. Although the discharge occurred "through" the metal skin and framework of the vehicle, it did not ignite the rocket's highly combustible fuel. * 1971 December 24: [[LANSA Flight 508]], a Lockheed L-188A Electra turboprop, registered OB-R-941, operated as a scheduled domestic passenger flight by Lineas Aéreas Nacionales Sociedad Anonima (LANSA), crashed after a lightning strike ignited a fuel tank while it was en route from Lima, Peru, to Pucallpa, Peru, killing 91 people – all of its 6 crew-members and 85 of its 86 passengers. The sole survivor was [[Juliane Koepcke]], who fell {{convert|2|mi|km}} down into the Amazon rainforest strapped to her seat and remarkably survived the fall, and was then able to walk through the jungle for 10 days until she was rescued by local lumbermen. * 2012 November 4: there were reports of a plane exploding off the coast of [[Herne Bay, Kent]], while in flight. This did not turn out to be the case, rather the plane became part of the flash channel, causing observers to report the plane and surrounding sky appeared bright pink.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kentonline.co.uk/kent/news/the-whole-plane-turned-pink-l-a59010/ |title=Low-flying cargo aircraft hit by lightning over Herne Bay|publisher=kentonline.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-11-04}}</ref>
=== Most-stricken human ===
* [[Roy Sullivan]] holds a [[Guinness World Record]] after surviving 7 different lightning strikes.<ref>{{cite news | title = Roy Sullivan | publisher = The New York Times Archives (from UPI) | date = 1983-09-30| url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9406E5D61F38F933A0575AC0A965948260 | accessdate = July 28, 2007}}</ref> He had multiple injuries across his body.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060428080854/http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/content_pages/record.asp?recordid=48497 Most Lightning Strikes Survived]. guinnessworldrecords.com (archived)</ref>
== See also == * [[Fulgurite]]s – a cloud-to-ground lightning discharge event can produce "petrified lightning", demonstrating the enormous, albeit brief, amount of energy transferred by lightning column. They can visually demonstrate how energy may internally or externally diffuse from one or several central nodes of the termination, and differences between the diameters of these channels, which range from only a few mm to several cm. The possible range of forms and compositions of fulgurites vary dramatically, reflecting the complex electrical, chemical, and physical properties of a target sediment, rock, or biological mass. * [[Geomagnetically induced current|Geomagnetically induced currents (GIC)]] – phenomena related to space radiation causing [[Transient (oscillation)|transients]] and [[Voltage spike|electrical irregularities]] that impact electrical and data transmission systems on a broad scale. Flash EMPS and ground currents operate in the same manner; however, they are more frequent and have much more localized effects on our technological world. * [[Keraunopathy]] – the medical study of lightning casualties and associated treatment
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [https://science.nasa.gov/newhome/headlines/essd18jun99_1.htm When lightning strikes people -NASA] * [http://www.lightningsafety.noaa.gov/safety.shtml Lightning Safety Page – National Weather Service Pueblo Colorado] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FwvxyzTNbVM Video footage - A Beech tree (Fagus sylvatica) that has been hit by lightning.]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lightning Strike}} [[Category:Lightning]]
[[ay:Lliju lliju]]

revision.comment: /* Aftermath */ Edit for comprehension
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox aircraft occurrence | name = Linjeflyg Flight 277 | date = 20 November 1964 | image = Linjeflyg Metropolitan SE-CCM.jpg | caption = A Linjeflyg Convair 440-75 Metropolitan sister-ship to the accident aircraft | image_size = 300px | type = [[Controlled flight into terrain]] | occurrence_type = Accident | site = [[Ängelholm]], Sweden | fatalities = 31 | injuries = 9 | aircraft_type = [[Convair CV-240 family|Convair 440 Metropolitan]] | operator = [[Linjeflyg]] | tail_number = SE-CCK | passengers = 39 | crew = 4 | survivors = 12 | origin = [[Stockholm Bromma Airport]] | stopover = [[Hultsfred Airport]] | stopover1 = [[Halmstad Airport]] | destination = [[Ängelholm–Helsingborg Airport]] }}
'''Linjeflyg Flight 277''' was a [[controlled flight into terrain]] by a [[Convair 440|Convair 440-75 Metropolitan]] on 20 November 1964 at 21:14 in [[Ängelholm Municipality|Ängelholm]], [[Skåne]], Sweden. The [[Linjeflyg]] pilots, misled by a non-conventional military [[runway light]] configuration, descended too early and on a faulty course during approach to [[Ängelholm–Helsingborg Airport]]. The crash killed 31 of 43 people on board, making it the deadliest aviation accident in Sweden.
The flight was en route from Stockholm to Ängelholm, but bad weather caused it to skip stopovers at [[Hultsfred]] and [[Halmstad]]. There was less than {{convert|2.0|km|sp=us}} visibility and a low [[cloud base]] at Ängelholm, so air traffic control lit its [[approach lighting system]]. As the civilian sector at Swedish Air Force base [[F 10 Ängelholm|F 10 Ängelholm]], the airport had a military configuration and did not follow normal civilian configuration. This caused a [[pilot error]] in the navigation and the aircraft landed {{convert|2.0|km|sp=us}} before the runway threshold. The aircraft inverted while sliding after impact. Despite the death toll, three people walked uninjured from the crash.
The investigation commission found no fault of the pilot or air traffic control, instead focusing on short-cuts being taken by the [[Swedish Air Force]] and the [[Swedavia|Civil Aviation Administration]] (CAA) to not configure military airports in line with civilian regulations. The finding caused a surge of funding which subsequently caused military airports to change their [[instrument landing system]] and [[approach lighting system]] to meet civilian requirements.
==Flight== The accident aircraft was a Convair CV-340-62, which had been converted to a CV-440 Metropolitan. It had production date 23 June 1954 and was delivered to [[Real Transportes Aéreos]] of Brazil on 17 November 1955, where it was registered as PP-YRC. It became the property of [[Varig]] with the merger of the two airlines in August 1961. This made the aircraft superfluous and it was subsequently sold to Linjeflyg on 13 December 1961 through the holding company Airtaco. The aircraft was registered in Sweden on 14 March 1962 as SE-CCK. It was subsequently sent to [[Oslo]] for conversion to CV-440 Metroliner. Ownership was transferred from Airtaco to its owner, ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'', in 1962. They sold it to [[Aerotransport]] on 1 October 1964.<ref>{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=343}}</ref>
Flight 267 was a scheduled, domestic service which was scheduled to fly from [[Stockholm Bromma Airport]] to Ängelholm–Helsingborg Airport, with intermediate stops at [[Hultsfred Airport]] and [[Halmstad Airport]]. Due to poor weather it was decided that the aircraft would not land at Hultsfred and the flight code was changed to FL 267V to reflect this. The aircraft had a flight crew of four, of which one of the two flight attendants was under training. Thirty-nine passengers boarded the aircraft in Stockholm, including one child and three members of [[Parliament of Sweden|Parliament]]. It departed Bromma at 19:46. It cruised at an altitude of 3,600 meters (12,000 ft). While en-route increasing fog was observed at Halmstad and the meteorologist at Ängelholm recommended that the aircraft bypass Halmstad and fly directly to Ängelholm.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 97">{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=97}}</ref>
[[File:Ängelholm airport 2007.JPG|thumb|Aerial view of [[Ängelholm–Helsingborg Airport]]]] Ängelholm–Helsingborg Airport was primarily a military air station, denoted F 10 Ängelholm. Because of this its instrument landing system was configured significantly different from most civilian airports. The runway's two [[radio beacon]]s, LJ and J, were located at unusual distances from normal. LJ was situated {{convert|10.4|km|sp=us}} from the runway threshold instead of the normal {{convert|7|km|sp=us}} and J was located at {{convert|3080|m|sp=us}} instead of the normal {{convert|1200|m|sp=us}}. Also, the approach lighting system's strobeacon was located {{convert|2250|m|sp=us}} from and {{convert|110|m|sp=us}} starboard of the runway's center line, but this light was not indicated on the instrument, approach and landing chart. Therefore, any aircraft which would pass beacon and aimed for the approach light would be aligned to land right of the runway.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 98">{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=98}}</ref>
Ängelholm was experiencing rain and visibility between {{convert|1.5|and|2.0|km|sp=us|1}}. The [[cloud base]] was only {{convert|60|m|sp=us}}. The crew considered diverting to another suitable location, such as [[Bulltofta Airport|Malmö Bulltofta Airport]] and [[Copenhagen Airport]], or even returning to Stockholm,<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 97"/> but upon reaching Halmstad the pilots chose to make a direct approach to Ängelholm runway 14 using [[visual flight rules]]. Given the weather conditions this was a highly unusual landing plan: normal procedure would be to turn northwest and carry out an [[instrument approach]] instead.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 98"/>
==Accident== Ängelholm tower contacted the flight crew at 20:57 and issued the latest weather report, which was for a slight clearing. At 21:08 the pilots confirmed that they were at an altitude of 600 meters (2,000 ft) and that they were aiming for LJ. The tower informed the pilots that they had lit a strobeacon, which was (incorrectly) said to be located on the runway center line, {{convert|2.5|km|sp=us}} from the threshold (it was actually 110m off center, to the right). At 21:13:10 the tower commenced directing the flight of the aircraft, asking it to fly to the left, as the air traffic controller could see it was off course. The last transmission from the aircraft was made at 21:13:47.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 98"/>
The aircraft was off course and at too low an altitude. This was discovered by the pilots prior to impact and they attempted to pull the aircraft up, but hit a field with its starboard wing tip and landing gear. It succeeded at ascending slightly, but continued to fly nearly at ground level. Eighty meters (260 ft) later it collided with the [[overhead line]]s of the [[West Coast Line (Sweden)|West Coast Railway Line]], knocking off two concrete posts. It continued for another {{convert|170|m|sp=us}} before hitting ground,<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 98"/> at which point it inverted. It slid for another {{convert|150|m|sp=us}} before coming to a halt, {{convert|40|m|sp=us}} from a house. Fire broke out in some of the wreck parts, although not in the main section of fuselage.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 99">{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=99}}</ref>
Thirty-one people on board were killed, including both the pilots. Three of the survivors were not injured, including the flight attendants. Some of the survivors were able to free themselves and each other and walk out of the fuselage. Most were hanging in their seat belts, wedged in by the wreckage. The fire departments in Ängelholm and [[Vejbystrand]] arrived at the scene eleven minutes after the crash and started freeing the survivors. The airport's rescue service was on the scene seventeen minutes after the accident. Nine people were seriously injured and were brought to the field hospital at the air base.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 99"/> The survivors were generally seated in the aft of the cabin.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 100">{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=100}}</ref> One of the passengers had brought their cat along in a cage on the flight, and it survived the accident.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 103">{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=103}}</ref>
==Investigation== An ''ad hoc'' investigation was appointed and later that night a [[Douglas DC-3]] of officials and experts from the airline and the CAA were dispatched to Ängelholm. The commission carried out test flights to Ängelholm and concluded that it was fully possible for the pilot to mistake the strobeacon for the centerline lights, though the finding was not conclusive as the two types of lighting are still somewhat distinctive. Linjeflyg pilots reported that they had previously made the same mistake, but that the issue had otherwise always been detected and they had corrected their course, landing safely. A quarter of Linjeflyg's pilots were not aware of the strobeacon.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 102">{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=102}}</ref>
During the investigation there was a large media coverage of a dispute between the [[Swedish Airline Pilots Association]] (SPF) and the [[Swedish Air Traffic Controllers Association]] (SFTF). The former accused the F 10 air traffic control for not following correct civil aviation procedures. SFTF responded by an official letter to the government questioning why the pilots were represented in the commission, as this could pose a potential conflict of interest. Both parties were criticized for speculating about the cause of the accident before the conclusion of the commission.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 103"/>
The commission stated that the probable cause of the accident was that the crew had carried out a premature descent. This was caused by the crew misunderstanding the lighting arrangement at the airport due to lack of proper information about its configuration.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 102"/> The report did not criticize the pilots for choosing to land with visual flight rules, nor for carrying out the landing in the encountered weather conditions. The commission found that no individuals were at fault in the incident and that it had been caused by a series of system errors. It placed responsibility with both the CAA and the Air Force for the inadequate configuration of the lighting system and for not properly following civilian regulations at military airports.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 103"/>
==Aftermath== After the accident Linjeflyg resumed service to Ängelholm with [[Douglas DC-3]] aircraft.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 102"/> The airline changed its procedures regarding landing at Ängelholm, making more strict policies in regard to minimum visibility. Both radio beacons were moved to the conventional civilian locations.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 102"/> Flight 277 was the seventh loss of a Convair CV-240 family aircraft. At the time it was deadliest and now remains the fifth-deadliest accident of the type. The accident remains the deadliest aviation accident in Sweden.<ref name=asn>{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19641120-0 |title=Friday 20 November 1964 |publisher=[[Aviation Safety Network]] |date=24 April 2014}}</ref> Linjeflyg would suffer one other fatal accident, [[Linjeflyg Flight 618|Flight 618]] in 1977, although it was a [[wet lease]] operated by [[Skyline (Sweden)|Skyline]].<ref>{{harvnb|Sanz|2006|p=168}}</ref>
The power balance between the CAA and the [[Swedish Air Force]] prior to the accident was skewed whereby the latter permitted civilian flights to their air bases on the condition that they did not intervene in military operations and procedures. The commission’s findings caused an increased focus on safety by the Civil Aviation Administration and a shift in attitude. Specifically, the military air bases with joint traffic were reconfigured to meet international civil standards in their instrument landing and lighting systems. This was made possible because the government, in the wake of the accident, increased funding to the CAA to improve the systems.<ref name="Sanz (2006), p. 103"/>
==Gallery== <Gallery> Linjeflyg Flight 277 (1).jpg|The day after the crash. The passengers' belongings are gathered. Linjeflyg Flight 277 (2).jpg|The day after the crash. Picture of the plane. Linjeflyg Flight 277 (3).jpg|The day after the crash. The passengers' belongings are gathered. </Gallery>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== *{{cite book |last=Sanz |first=Michael |title=Linjeflyg: ett folkflyg från start till landning |edition=2nd |year=2006 |publisher=Allt om hobby |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=91-7243-038-9 |id={{LIBRIS|10154585}} |ref=harv}}

{{refimprove|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox automobile |name = Mercedes-Benz O405 |image = Mercedes-Benz O 405 Viernheim 100 2269.jpg |caption = Mercedes O405 (integral) in Viernheim |manufacturer = [[Mercedes-Benz buses|Mercedes-Benz]] |production = 1983−2001 |assembly = [[Mannheim]], Germany |predecessor = [[Mercedes-Benz O305]] (single decker and articulated) |successor = [[Mercedes-Benz Citaro]] (O530)
[[Mercedes-Benz OC500LE]] |class = [[Bus manufacturing|Complete bus]]
[[Bus]] [[chassis]] |doors = 1 or 2 doors (rigid)
2 or 3 doors (articulated) |floortype = [[High-floor|High floor]]
[[Low-floor bus|Low floor]]
[[Low-entry bus|Low entry]] |capacity = 60 to 104 passengers (35 seated to 61 seated) |engine = OM447h (157 kW)
OM447h (177 kW)
OM447hII (184 kW)
OM447hLA (184 kW) |transmission = Mercedes-Benz W3E110/2.2R
Mercedes-Benz W3E112/2.2R
Mercedes-Benz W4E
[[Allison Transmission|Allison]] B400R
[[Voith DIWA]] 851.2
Voith DIWA 864.3
[[ZF Friedrichshafen|ZF]] 4HP500
ZF 5HP500 |length = 11.1 m
11.7 m
12.2 m (rigid)/17.1m, 18.0m (articulated) |width = 2.5 m |layout = [[Rear-engine design|Rear-engine]] |related = }} The '''Mercedes-Benz O405''' was a highly successful [[single-decker bus]] manufactured by [[Mercedes-Benz buses|Mercedes-Benz]] from the mid-1980s to the early 2000s as either an [[Bus manufacturing|integral bus]] or a bus chassis and was the last [[VöV-Standard-Bus|VöV SL-II standard bus]] in production. It was the replacement for the [[Mercedes-Benz O305]] and was widely used in Europe, the United Kingdom, Australia and Singapore. ==Standard floor version== The [[High-floor|step-entrance]] version was known as the O405. A 3-axle [[Articulated bus|articulated version]] was also built known as O405G. There were two generations of O405, designated as O405 MkI and O405 MkII. Most of them have their boxy roof dome (slightly arched) with a double-curvature windscreen, separately mounted [[destination blind|destination indicator]] and pantograph system [[windshield wiper]]s that was used on some buses such as the [[Dennis Dart]], [[Leyland Lynx]], [[MAN NL262]] and the [[MAN SL202]]. ===O405 MkI=== The O405 MkI was marketed between mid-1980s and early 1990s. It featured a Mercedes Benz OM447h naturally aspirated engine with outputs of either 157[[kW]] (210[[Horsepower|hp]]) or 184 kW (250 hp). Optionally available was a naturally aspirated [[compressed natural gas]] (CNG) engine model M447hG with 150 kW (205 hp) output. The gearbox coupled to the engine was usually the Mercedes-Benz W3E110/2.2R or Mercedes-Benz W3E112/2.2R (the former being able to handle the more powerful 184 kW engine), although there have been other gearboxes such as the [[ZF Friedrichshafen|ZF]] 5HP 500 or [[Allison Transmission|Allison]] B300R coupled to the engine. ===O405 MkII=== The O405 MkII was marketed from the early 1990s to the late 1990s and into the early 2000s in some parts of the world. It featured a Mercedes-Benz OM447hA turbocharged engine with an output of 184 kW (250 hp), although some examples feature either a naturally aspirated engine (OM447h-II), a turbocharged engine (OM447hA) or a turbocharged, intercooled engine (OM447hLA). The gearbox coupled to the engine was either the [[ZF Friedrichshafen|ZF]] 4HP 500 or 5HP 500, or the [[Voith]] D864.3. From 1994, this chassis was available with the M447hG [[Euro II]] 175 kW (238 hp) naturally aspirated [[compressed natural gas]] (CNG) engine. {{clear right}} ==Low-floor version== [[File:Coventry travel bus32 27a07 (cropped).JPG|thumb|[[National Express Coventry|Travel Coventry]] integral O405N low floor in April 2007]] The [[low-floor bus|low-floor]] version of the regular O405 was known as the O405N (or O405GN for the 3-axle [[Articulated bus|articulated]] version), later a further developed version was also built, it was known as the O405N²/O405N2 (or O405GN²/O405GN2 for the 3-axle articulated version). The O405(G)N do not have steps at the entrances and exits, but the seats are mounted on "platforms". The GN2 type addressed this problem. These buses are usually fitted with ZF transmissions, but some are fitted with [[Voith]] examples. It has a boxy roof dome (slightly arched) similar to the [[MAN NL202]] and the [[MAN NL262]] with a double-curvature windscreen with a separately mounted [[destination blind|destination display]] just that it has a full [[Low-floor bus|low floor]] layout with seats mounted on platforms. {{clear right}} ==Low-entry version O405 NH== [[File:Transperth 2001 Volgren CR225L bodied Mercedes-Benz O405NH diesel (Swan Transit).jpg|thumb|[[Transperth]] [[Volgren]] bodied O405NH CNG in October 2018]] The [[Low-entry bus|low-entry]] version of the O405 was called the O405NH chassis was produced by [[EvoBus]] for the Australian market. Much of its popularity with government and private operators alike can be attributed to the popularity of the Mercedes-Benz O405 MkII chassis that it replaced. The chassis was derived from a combination of the rear modules of an O405 MkII chassis and the front modules of an O405N²/O405GN² chassis. Because of the difference in height between the front and rear modules of the chassis, there are one or more steps leading up from behind the centre door position to a standard O405 floorline. Because the chassis has a horizontally-mounted engine, there's no room for a rear door. This "[[Low-entry bus|low-entry]]" concept has become very popular in [[Europe]] - many integral products using this concept have been released such as the [[Mercedes-Benz Citaro]] LE. == Suburban version == [[File:BRN bus MB O407 100 0355.jpg|thumb|right|O407 integral]] The suburban version was called O407 (or O407G for the 3-axle [[Articulated bus|articulated]] version), It had a single door at the front and a pair in the middle, with all of the seats facing towards the front of the bus. It featured a Mercedes Benz OM447h naturally aspirated engine with output 177[[kW]] (237[[Horsepower|hp]]) and 6-speed manual Mercedes-Benz gearbox.{{clear right}} ==Orders== ===Portugal=== * Camo U1001S * Camo Camus * Irmãos Mota Atomic UR95 and UR2000 * Marcopolo Tricana bodies ===Spain=== * Unicar * [[Tata Hispano|Hispano Carrocera]] * Castrosua ===United Kingdom=== [[File:Mercedes Wright Cityranger 1.jpg|thumb|[[First Greater Manchester]] [[Wright Endurance|Wright CityRider]] bodied O405 in [[Manchester]] in July 2007]] A total of 365 O405s were built for operators in the United Kingdom, with [[National Express West Midlands|Travel West Midlands]] purchasing 204.[http://www.buslistsontheweb.co.uk/index.htm?http://www.buslistsontheweb.co.uk/list.asp?listname=712&Type=Chassis Mercedes-Benz O405] Bus Lists on the Web A sole O405Gs was bodied by [[Walter Alexander Coachbuilders|Alexander]] for [[First Aberdeen|Grampian Regional Transport]].[http://www.buslistsontheweb.co.uk/index.htm?http://www.buslistsontheweb.co.uk/list.asp?listname=713&Type=Chassis Mercedes-Benz O405G / O405GN] Bus Lists on the Web[http://archive.commercialmotor.com/article/6th-february-1992/16/top-spec-artic-by-walter-alexander Top spec artic by Walter Alexander] ''[[Commercial Motor]]'' 6 February 1992 page 16 A total of 204 O405Ns were built for operators in the United Kingdom, with Travel West Midlands purchasing 193.[http://www.buslistsontheweb.co.uk/index.htm?http://www.buslistsontheweb.co.uk/list.asp?listname=714&Type=Chassis Mercedes-Benz O405N] Bus Lists on the Web A total of 15 O405GNs were built for operators in the United Kingdom, with Travel West Midlands purchasing 11. ===Hong Kong=== [[Discovery Bay|Discovery Bay Transit Services]] of Hong Kong acquired four O405 single-decker buses between 1995 and 1998, two were fitted with locally-built bodywork by Asia Auto Body Works and the other two had [[Tata Hispano|Hispano Carrocera]] bodywork.Chan, C. Y. Danny (June 2012). ''Hong Kong Bus Files: Mercedes-Benz O 305/O405 Bus''. Northcord International. {{ISBN|978-962-920-040-4}}. ===Australia=== [[File:Sydney Buses (mo 1298) Custom Coaches 'Citaro' bodied Mercedes-Benz O405NH CNG on Loftus Street in Circular Quay (cropped).jpg|thumb|[[State Transit Authority]] [[Custom Coaches]] bodied O405NH]] [[State Transit Authority|Sydney Buses]] took delivery of 247 [[Pressed Metal Corporation]] bodied O405s between 1987 and October 1990. The last were retired in early 2016. In January 1997 it received two [[Ansair]] bodied O405Ns. It also inherited four [[Custom Coaches]] bodied O405s when it purchased [[North & Western Bus Lines]]. Between October 1999 and December 2002 it received 300 Custom Coaches bodied [[compressed natural gas|CNG]] O405NHs with the O405NH discontinued after this order.[http://fleetlists.busaustralia.com/sta.php?flsummary=STA State Transit Authority] Bus Australia The 300 Custom Coaches 0405NH ordered by State Transit were delivered from Germany as a fully constructed frame and panels were fitted by Custom Coaches, so that as many of these buses could be on the road in time for the Sydney Olympic Games. They can seat 45 passengers and are 12.5 metres long. They have M447hG Euro 2 engines producing 175 kW. [[Transperth]] took delivery of 48 [[natural gas vehicle|natural gas]] and 349 diesel O405NHs. Other purchasers of O405s included [[Busways (New South Wales)|Busways]], [[Quince's Scenicruisers]] and [[ComfortDelGro Australia#Westbus|Westbus]]. ===Singapore=== [[File:TIB1105H on 169.jpg|thumb|[[SMRT Buses]] [[Hispano Carrocera|Hispano Habit]] bodied Mercedes-Benz O405G]] [[Singapore Bus Services]] ordered 700 Mercedes-Benz O405 to replace its first batch of Mercedes-Benz OF1413s between 1990 and 1992. They were bodied by [[Alexander PS]] and [[Duple Metsec]] (OAC (original air-con) and NAC (non-aircon)). The non air-con buses were later converted to air-con buses in 1998-99. All were withdrawn from 1 March 2008 to 3 June 2011 with all replaced by [[Scania K UB|Scania K230UB]]. A few O405s were shipped to [[Thailand]] and were rebodied due to the bodywork being no longer designed whereas the rest of them were scrapped and only one unit was converted by the [[National Library Board]]. [[Trans-Island Bus Services]] bought Mercedes-Benz O405 with [[Hispano Carrocera]] (OAC (original air-con) and CAC (converted air-con) and [[Volgren|Volgren CR221]] bodies to replace the ageing [[Nissan Diesel UA|Nissan U31RCN]]{{when|date=November 2016}}. All Mercedes-Benz O405 with [[Hispano Carrocera]] bodywork had been retired by 25 September 2016. The Volgren-bodied O405s on the other hand are used as permanent [[training bus]]es. It was fully retired by late February 2017. TIBS had bought for the first time, various batch of bendy buses (Hispano MK1 using the box body, Hispano MK2 using parts from Mercedes-Benz O530 Citaro, Hispano Habit and Volgren) bodies between 1996 and 2004. They will be retiring by 1 January 2019. {{cn|date=July 2018}} ===Russia=== * GolAZ (Golitsynskii avtobusnyi zavod) produced model O405 (АКА-5225) and O405G (АКА-6226) ==Replacement== Production of the Mercedes-Benz O405 ended in 2002 when the last bendy buses were delivered to [[Trans-Island Bus Services]]. The Mercedes-Benz O405 / O405N series was superseded by the [[Mercedes-Benz Citaro|Citaro]], and the O405NH was superseded by the [[Mercedes-Benz OC500LE|OC500LE]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline|Mercedes-Benz O 405}}
{{Commons category-inline|Mercedes-Benz O 405 N}}
{{Commons category-inline|Mercedes-Benz O 405 NH}}

revision.comment: Added "was" in "units in the solid state [was] first determined in 1926"
revision.text:
'''Mercury polycations''' are [[polyatomic]] cations that contain only [[mercury (element)|mercury]] atoms. The best known example is the {{chem|Hg|2|2+}} ion, found in mercury(I) (mercurous) compounds. The existence of the metal-metal bond in Hg(I) compounds was established using X-ray studies in 1927<ref name = "Wells3d">Wells A.F. (1962) ''Structural Inorganic Chemistry'' 3d edition Oxford Science Publications</ref> and Raman spectroscopy in 1934<ref name = "Greenwood">{{Greenwood&Earnshaw}}</ref> making it one of the earliest, if not the first, covalent metal-metal bonds to be characterised.
Other mercury polycations are the linear {{chem|Hg|3|2+}} and {{chem|Hg|4|2+}} ions,<ref name = "Greenwood"/> and the triangular {{chem|Hg|3|4+}} ion <ref name ="Broderson">Terlinguait, Hg<sub>4</sub>O<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub> - ein Mineral mit ungewöhnlichen Hg<sub>3</sub>-Baueinheiten, K. Brodersen,G. Göbel, G. Liehr, Zeitschrift für anorganische und allgemeine Chemie, 575, 1, 1989, 145 - 153, {{doi|10.1002/zaac.19895750118}}</ref> and a number of chain<ref name = "Brown">Alchemists' Gold, Hg<sub>2.86</sub> AsF<sub>6</sub>; An X-Ray Crystallographic Study of A Novel Disordered Mercury Compound Containing Metallically Bonded Infinite Cations, I. David Brown, Brent D. Cutforth, Colin G. Davies, Ronald J. Gillespie, Peter R. Ireland, and John E. Vekris, Can. J. Chem. 52(5): 791-793 (1974),{{doi|10.1139/CJC-52-5-791}}</ref> and layer polycations.<ref name = "Brown2">{{Cite journal| last1 = Brown | first1 = I. D.| last2 = Gillespie | first2 = R. J.| last3 = Morgan | first3 = K. R.| last4 = Tun | first4 = Z.| last5 = Ummat | first5 = P. K.| title = Preparation and crystal structure of mercury hexafluoroniobate ({{chem|Hg|3|NbF|6}}) and mercury hexafluorotantalate ({{chem|Hg|3|TaF|6}}): mercury layer compounds| journal = Inorganic Chemistry| volume = 23| issue = 26| pages = 4506–4508| year = 1984 | doi = 10.1021/ic00194a020}}</ref>
==Mercury(I)==
The best known polycation of mercury is {{chem|Hg|2|2+}}, in which mercury has a formal oxidation state of +1. The {{chem|Hg|2|2+}} ion was perhaps the first metal-metal bonded species confirmed. The presence of the {{chem|Hg|2|2+}} ion in solution was shown by Ogg in 1898.<ref>A. Ogg; Zeitschrift Physische Chemie 27, 285 (1898)</ref> In 1900, Baker showed the presence of HgCl dimers in the vapour phase.<ref>Vapour density of dried mercurous chloride, H. Brereton Baker M.A., J. Chem. Soc., Trans., 1900, 77, 646, {{doi|10.1039/CT9007700646}}</ref> The presence of {{chem|Hg|2|2+}} units in the solid state was first determined in 1926 using X-ray diffraction.<ref name = "Wells3d"/> The presence of the metal-metal bond in solution was confirmed using Raman spectroscopy in 1934.<ref name = "Greenwood"/>
{{chem|Hg|2|2+}} is stable in aqueous solution, where it is in equilibrium with {{chem|Hg|2+}} and elemental Hg, with {{chem|Hg|2+}} present at around 0.6%.<ref name = "Greenwood"/> This equilibrium is readily shifted by the addition of an anion which forms an insoluble Hg(II) salt, such as [[sulfide|{{chem|S|2-}}]], which causes the Hg(I) salt to completely disproportionate, or by the addition of an anion which forms an insoluble Hg(I) salt, such as [[chloride|{{chem|Cl|-}}]], which causes the elemental mercury and Hg<sup>2+</sup> to completely recombine into the mercury(I) salt.<ref name = "Greenwood"/>
Minerals that are known that contain the {{chem|Hg|2|2+}} cation include [[eglestonite]].<ref>Eglestonite, [Hg<sub>2</sub>]<sub>3</sub>Cl<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>H: Confirmation of the chemical formula by neutron powder diffraction, Mereiter K., Zemann J., Hewatt A.W. American Mineralogist, 77, (1992), 839-842</ref>
==Linear trimercury and tetramercury cations==
Compounds containing the linear {{chem|Hg|3|2+}} (mercury({{frac|2|3}})) and {{chem|Hg|4|2+}} (mercury({{frac|1|2}})) cations have been synthesised. These ions are only known in the solid state in compounds such as {{chem|Hg|3|(AlCl|4|)|2}} and {{chem|Hg|4|(AsF|6|)|2}}.<ref name = "Greenwood"/> The Hg–Hg bond length is 255 pm in {{chem|Hg|3|2+}}, and 255–262 pm in {{chem|Hg|4|2+}}.<ref name = "Greenwood"/> The bonding involves 2-centre-2-electron bonds formed by 6s orbitals.<ref name = "Greenwood"/>
==Cyclic mercury cations==
The triangular {{chem|Hg|3|4+}} cation was confirmed in a reinvestigation of the mineral [[terlinguaite]] in 1989<ref name ="Broderson"/> and subsequently synthesised in a number of compounds.<ref>[Hg<sub>3</sub>]<sup>4+ </sup>Cation in Inorganic Crystal Structures, S. V. Borisov, S. A. Magarill and N. V. Pervukhina, Journal of Structural Chemistry, 44, 3, 2003, 441-447, {{doi|10.1023/B:JORY.0000009672.71752.68}}</ref> The bonding has been described in terms of a [[three-center two-electron bond]] where overlap of the 6s orbitals on the mercury atoms gives (in D<sub>3h</sub> symmetry) a bonding "a<sub>1</sub>" orbital.<ref>Synthesis and crystal structure of the subvalent mercury cluster [triangulo-Hg<sub>3</sub>(-dmpm)<sub>4</sub>][O<sub>3</sub>SCF<sub>3</sub>]<sub>4</sub> (dmpm = Me<sub>2</sub>PCH<sub>2</sub>PMe<sub>2</sub>), Anna Mühlecker-Knoepfler, Ernst Ellmerer-Müller, Robert Konrat, Karl-Hans Ongania, Klaus Wurst and Paul Peringer, J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans., 1997, 1607 - 1610, {{doi|10.1039/a700483d}}</ref>
==Chain and layer polycations== The golden yellow compound {{chem|Hg|2.86|(AsF|6}}), named "alchemists' gold" by its discoverers,<ref name = "Brown"/> contains perpendicular chains of Hg atoms.
The "metallic" compounds {{chem|Hg|3|NbF|6}} and {{chem|Hg|3|TaF|6}} contain hexagonal layers of mercury atoms separated by layers of {{chem|MF|6|−}} anions.<ref name = "Brown2"/> They are both [[superconductor]]s below 7 [[Kelvin|K]].<ref>Superconductivity of Hg<sub>3</sub>NbF<sub>6</sub> and Hg<sub>3</sub>TaF<sub>6</sub>,(1983),W. R. Datars, K. R. Morgan and R. J. Gillespie, Phys. Rev. B 28, 5049 - 5052, {{doi|10.1103/PhysRevB.28.5049}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Mercury compounds}}
